output: Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Mr Sibep for the work he has done, because his report addresses many of the concerns expressed here.

The camera focuses on these crucial issues for the entire European Union. These are water scarcity and drought, matters that have already ceased to be a problem only for the countries of southern Europe.

I am pleased that this project incorporates some of the reflections made in the opinion report for which I was rapporteur in the Committee on Agriculture in favor of agricultural activity, highlighting, for example, the role that farmers play in the sustainable management of available resources.

It also includes a reference to drought and water scarcity as factors that exacerbate prices in raw materials, an aspect that I also think is very important to point out in the current times, so that we keep in mind not only the environmental dimension of this problem, but also some of its most relevant economic consequences.

The Committee on the Environment also included the idea of creating a European Drought Observatory, an action that is also mentioned in the report of the Committee on Agriculture and which I hope will one day be reflected in concrete actions.

The text that will be put to a vote tomorrow, however, includes a proposal made by the Committee on Agriculture to study the establishment of an economic adaptation fund against drought, a fund that would benefit all economic sectors, including agriculture.

For my part, I would like to make it clear that I will continue to defend the establishment of this fund, an idea that I will propose again to Parliament when the Commission publishes its communication on adaptation to climate change in the coming months.

I believe that after the Solidarity Fund was established, which was created to mitigate losses caused by climate calamities, it is time for us to think about an instrument that acts beforehand and is intended to finance prevention measures to reduce the environmental and economic cost of these climate disasters.

But the case goes beyond the particular, as these federal bodies aggravate the sanctions for those who resort to ordinary justice.

And we will end up doing it because those medieval gentlemen, arbitrary hangmen and knife-wielders, must align themselves with respect for the law and the ordinary procedural guarantees of our Europe.

I have taken good note of the answers you have given to the relevant questions. It is true that guarantees must be demanded, it is true that it is a sensitive issue, but it is no less true that it is absolutely inexcusable to put together, to form a globalized and harmonized response.
For some, terrorism is a bit far removed from their concerns, and they are more worried about individual guarantees.
I am concerned about both individual and collective issues. And it is absolutely necessary that we start where we can.
If we have started with air transport, where companies already have that data, let's start there.

Let us demand guarantees, see what the scope is, start with international transport relations and, be careful, we will have to follow up on domestic ones because terrorists often do not come from outside, but from within.
ask the United States and ask others, that's the way it is and that's how we'll have to approach it.
Thank you, Mr. President. I want to thank the committee that has presented this proposal.
I believe it is a positive proposal and that it will help us reduce unnecessary administrative burdens.
Now, as the speakers who preceded me have said, this Parliament has the obligation to bring down to earth what are very generous and very altruistic proposals on the part of the Commission.

And the reality is that there is a national reality in which there are 27 countries with different legal systems and very different languages, which requires that in each of those countries we adapt to the realities of the country, including the issue of languages.

Specifically, as Gosset pointed out just now and as previous speakers have noted, it is important that the recognition of these national specialties does not lead to an increase in costs, that the fees are uniform, and that governments eventually assume that additional cost.
But there is one theme that also appears, which is the theme of translations.
Concretely, in the European Union we do not have a common language,
In the 27 countries, very different languages are usually spoken, even in some countries, like the Commissioner's, different languages are spoken and we live with this.
And from a legal point of view, we are also faced with the reality that legal documents are different.
In the Legal Commission, the Legal Commission has proposed, for example, amendments on the authentication of minutes, of documents, along with the authentication of the translation.
At the moment, the Committee on Legal Affairs is preparing a report on the recognition of authentic instruments in different countries of the European Union, which should complement this report.
In conclusion, I believe that the committee has done well in presenting this report
The rapporteur has done a magnificent job and I believe we have all strived to draft a legislative proposal that can be recognized throughout the Union, guaranteeing citizens' rights.
rights and starting from the basis of the reality of a union that is being built, which has different national systems and which has different levels of access to electronic communication.

Thank you, Mr. President. A large majority of farmers and ranchers are awaiting the decisions and prior agreements that the Council of Ministers of Agriculture of the Union will adapt between today and tomorrow regarding this economic check-up.
the CAP, because it is not a simple review, but will bring about profound changes, such as the disappearance of many farms. This cut proposed by the European Commission on direct aid is going ahead.

Modulation is the focal point of this parliamentary report and could be one of the few elements of Parliament's opinion to have any impact on the negotiations being conducted by the EU's Agriculture Ministers.
We have been opposing for years any increase in what we euphemistically call modulation, because if the rural development policy does not have sufficient funds, it is not possible.
not due to a lack of resources within the CAP expenditure ceiling, but due to an absolute absence of political will to provide the Community budget with the necessary development of this key pillar.
Pilar. Do you want to liberalize the markets?
Sure, do it, but with the same requirements and conditions for all producers, both inside and outside the Union.

At this moment, the European Union is deciding the future of many farmers and ranchers, and I would especially like to refer to fragile sectors such as sheep, cattle, and tobacco, whose survival in many producing areas will depend on this review.

Some producers, such as those in the sheep industry, no longer ask for aid, but simply want to be allowed to leave the market with dignity, because they have done the math and the only way to survive is to reduce the volumes produced.

The abandonment of production, therefore, is the only option we are leaving to many producers, whose space will undoubtedly be occupied by imports from third countries, because consumers will not stop consuming and the world will not stop increasing the number of consumers at a rapid pace.
Parliament should issue a prudent opinion and the Council should listen to it.

I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Chairman of the Committee on Agriculture for the efforts made by Mr. Pérez to ensure that Parliament is heard and not so blatantly and obviously ignored by the Council and the Commission as has been the case up to now.
Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, I would like to join in congratulating the rapporteur, Mr. Capula Santos, for his excellent work.
I think he has found balance and moderation in his report.
I believe that what is important at this stage of the debate is to send a message of stability to our farmers.
European farmers need stability and solutions more than ever.
Sufficient transitional periods are necessary, as well as maintaining specific measures that are necessary for sectors in difficulty.
Commissioner, the same solutions do not work for all sectors.
And we must remember that we have sectors that are going through real difficulties.
The common agricultural policy does not have to be the problem, but the solution. And for that, we need a strong first pillar.
We believe in and support rural development, but we do not believe that the modulation proposed by the Commission is the solution.
It is not about strengthening rural development at the expense of the first pillar.
We agree that the single payment scheme needs to be simplified, and that market instruments need to be reviewed.
But that doesn't mean dismantling them.
If we do it right, we will be laying the foundations for a common agricultural policy beyond 2013. If not, we will be putting an end to the activity of many European farmers.
We are facing a plan that has been highly anticipated by the fruit sector, not only because of the difficulties it is experiencing, but also because of the worrying decline in consumption.
We are dealing with a public health promotion plan. I believe it should be a European plan and I also advocate for full Community funding.

I don't agree that parents can participate in co-financing, because the same thing will happen as always. The children of parents who can contribute money will consume fruits and vegetables at school, while those who can't will be left out of the program.
I believe it has to be a community-funded plan for its distribution to be homogeneous.
That is why I also want to strongly emphasize that we must focus on educational measures.

It's not just about a student eating an apple, but knowing what kind of apple they are eating. They should be aware of its nutritional properties and understand the beneficial effects that this fruit has on their health and development.

Of course, these must be products with all the quality guarantees, giving priority, if possible, to seasonal fruits and, whenever possible, I advocate for the Community origin of our fruits and vegetables.

I believe that the beneficial effects of this plan, which I applaud and for which I want to congratulate the Commissioner, will be immediately noticeable. Of course, for the present and future health of our children and their current education.

But I also believe that it is very important for the fruit and vegetable sector, a productive sector that constitutes a genuine European cultural heritage. Thanks to it, we can enjoy a balanced, healthy and varied diet.
I believe it is worth betting on and investing in this plan to distribute fruits and vegetables in our schools.
I believe the budget falls a little short because I advocate for full community funding for a plan as ambitious as this.
Yes, thank you, Mr. President. I ask that you do not include these opening words, please, in the sick machine of time, because my questions are very important.
My first words are to join in the message of condolence expressed by this House to Mrs Clam and, above all, to congratulate the rapporteurs.
Now I'm really going to start.

I congratulate the rapporteurs because with these two proposals we are taking a significant step towards a common immigration policy and are promoting legal immigration, a key pillar of the comprehensive approach we advocate.
The general framework of rights and the single residence and work permit for legal immigrants should be extended to as many workers as possible.
That is why socialists demand that no category of workers be excluded.
The so-called blue card provides an opportunity for migrants to settle with their families and work in our countries.
it opens up a unique door to 27 job markets.
However, this door should not only be used by highly skilled workers,
Therefore, we expect, Commissioner, that the Commission will soon present its proposals regarding the other occupational categories.
Ladies and gentlemen, we must fight against the brain drain.
This blue card must not become a passport that facilitates a drain of vital human resources from developing countries.
That is why, from the Socialist Group, we want that for every qualified professional who comes to Europe, we should pay for the training of a new professional in the country of origin.
Finally, Europe must be an attractive destination not only for talent from outside the Union, but also for our own.
In 2007, nearly 300,000 highly qualified Europeans left to work outside the Union.
Let's do everything possible to keep them in the European House.

Mr President, on behalf of the Socialist Group, I want to express my group's strongest condemnation of the murders being committed in this region of Somalia, invoking the name of God.
Few atrocities have been committed by someone who has not invoked the name of God or a religion.

Specifically, we already know the way this atrocious murder was committed: a 13-year-old girl is raped and then accused of adultery, and five men, if they can be called men, rush to stone her and even prevent anyone from trying to save her, in a stadium filled with a thousand people.
This, combined with the acts of piracy that have reached a level of nearly 100 hijacked ships off the coast of Somalia this year, constitutes an absolutely unacceptable humanitarian situation.
The international community cannot remain impassive in the face of this.
cannot remain impassive in the face of cowardice, in the face of religious invocation to commit barbarity,
Therefore, we must restore order by supporting the legitimate government of Somalia to regain control of the entire country and establish a rule of law that respects human rights.
I believe that rarely have we been presented with a situation that is so clear and that imposes obligations on us.
I don't believe we can stand idly by in this community of 500 million people and 27 countries, the most important in the world, without intervening in that situation.
I don't know how it can be done, but I certainly believe that it must be done and that we must act quickly.

I believe that the rapporteur and the speakers who preceded me have highlighted the characteristics of this proposal for a directive from Parliament and the Council.
It is a recognition that weapons and ammunition are also part of the internal market, although of course with a number of limitations.
These are not normal goods, they are not candies or entertainment items, but rather objects that require precise control.
Of course there are limitations in the treaty itself, Article 30 and Article 296, which confer important responsibilities on the States in this area.
And the fact that we have a common market does not prevent states from being obliged to comply with safety standards and from having the right to apply them when their own safety is at risk.

I believe our model is not one of free circulation of weapons at any time, but rather a regulated market, controlled by the states and also controlled from now on by the European Union's own institutions.

We have a proposed resolution on Nicaragua that needs to address different aspects.
First, there is an allegation of fraud, at least in two municipalities, Nicaragua and León, and this tarnishes the election result of November 9.

specifically poverty, illiteracy, infant mortality, the availability of potable water, and the lack of title to indigenous lands.
So, when examining the case, we have to clearly distinguish between the two aspects.

On the one hand, we need to promote human rights and defend human rights in the traditional sense as political rights. And on the other hand, we need to encourage the government of Nicaragua to continue its role in helping the most needy sectors of the country.
Of course, we must ensure that the opposition can exercise its function, we must oppose fraud, but we must also defend the actions of NGOs.
But, however, one must have a balanced result.

violations of fundamental rights, with respect to whether the investigations are criminal or not, and with respect to the number of municipalities in which some type of derogation has occurred.

On the situation created in Nicaragua by the attacks against some human rights defenders, against some fundamental freedoms and against democracy.

There is no need to recall here and now Soy la América, Ernesto Cardenal, Carlos Mejía Godoy, Jarquín, Sergio Ramírez, or the many other Nicaraguans who today feel betrayed in their hopes for a better Nicaragua.

Today we already know what she wanted it for.

President Ortega called the governments of the European Union flies that swarm over filth and described the foreign aid that Nicaragua received as crumbs.
soon he understood that there was not enough Venezuelan oil to do without that development aid.

But for us, the demand for respect for human rights, freedom of expression, and democracy in general, is a condition to which we will not renounce because we believe that the people of Nicaragua benefit from it especially.
Municipal elections were held in Nicaragua until November 9th.
As in previous occasions, this electoral process has been questioned from the point of view of democratic legitimacy, with accusations of fraud being made and curses being uttered.
demonstrations and clashes between supporters of different political parties, resulting in numerous injuries and a deepening of the political crisis that this country has been suffering from.
Two political parties have been unable to run in the local elections, which is unacceptable because it undermines the fundamental right of all citizens to political participation.

On the other hand, we have received direct testimonies from representatives of human rights organizations who have informed us about the existence of a questioning of the judicial system by civil society.

about the existence of administrative repression mechanisms that have brought up to 17 social movement organizations to court, about the persecution of independent journalists and even the delegation of the European Commission.

For all these reasons, we want to raise our voice and make an appeal, first to the political parties to condemn the acts of violence carried out by their followers and, second, to the government itself to reopen spaces for citizen participation.

citizen, that freedom of expression is respected, that marches are no longer banned, and that all NGOs can receive aid from international cooperation, not just those from Venezuela, for pro-government associations.
Likewise, that it repeal the penalization of therapeutic abortion in cases of danger to the life of the mother.

democracy and human rights, all of this without prejudice to the fact that from Europe we continue to provide our aid for the development and well-being of the Nicaraguan people, who we wish to have the best possible future.
Thank you, Madam President. I am going to refer to the Breyer report.
And I have to say that European farmers are fully aware that particular attention must be paid to human health and also to environmental protection when using plant protection products.
However, the sector is deeply concerned because the European Parliament does not understand the impact that this regulation may have in the future.
And there are assessments of its potential impact that indicate that due to the scarce future availability of plant protection products, it will be very difficult to
control of pests and diseases that affect the cultivation of large quantities of food, particularly all Mediterranean products, and also the cultivation of ornamental plants and cut flowers.
I am fully aware that the agreement reached in the tripartite dialogue has been the result of intense negotiations and I cannot fail to acknowledge the work done by the rapporteurs.

But nevertheless, it must be taken into account that the temporary definition of endocrine disruptors will lead to the disappearance of a large number of active substances, especially insecticides, which are of key importance for agriculture.

Producers must have a sufficient quantity of active substances available to effectively and safely combat any plant disease or pest, bearing in mind that the danger often lies not in the product itself, but in its misuse.
For all these reasons, the Spanish delegation of the PP-EDi Group......supports the proposals that call for an impact assessment......and will vote in favor of the amendments...
by Mr. Stardi, which I myself have signed, concerning endocrine disruptors and those that promote the availability of plant protection products in emergency cases.

Furthermore, if this regulation is adopted as per the terms of the agreement reached, the effects will be a reduction in food production and a rise in prices that will lead us to import the very foods we do not produce, treated with the products we are producing.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Capato, your report is a report that is full of good will. The most evident proof is that it did not deserve any amendments during its processing in the Committee on Freedoms.
Were you the one who introduced 18 amendments to your own report?
And those amendments are the ones that have introduced an added radicalism to that report, let's say in general terms, which gives me very serious doubts.
I would set out the amendments you have proposed in four distinct sections. You proposed them yourself, I insist, in a report that received support from all groups at the beginning.
Some impossible ones. You ask for some things that are impossible.

For example, Mr. Capato, you are asking for things for which there is no legal basis yet. For example, until the Lisbon Treaty comes into force, it will be impossible to harmonize the regulations of different committees.
Commissioner Wallström has just said something similar. Or you ask, for example, that we declare 2009 the year of transparency. We are late, there is no longer a deadline.
Therefore, you are asking for things that are impossible.
It also asks for some others that are not advisable.
For example, you ask for transparency in the meetings of the political groups.
No man no
privacy is necessary, privacy is a political asset.
If I want to disagree with my party, to maintain an opposition, I want to do it in private and that is not a lack of transparency.
Transparency must be demanded in public bodies, but not within the parties where debates must be guaranteed within privacy.
Therefore, I cannot follow you on that.
There are some other assessments you make, Mr. Capato, that are uncertain.
For example, you say that 90% of legislative activity is pro-committee.
That is a reckless exaggeration, Mr. Capato...
And, in addition, meteorology implies certain rules of transparency in itself.

If what we are going to do now is create more mechanisms, more bureaucracy, more controls, we will be going against what we want to pursue, which is transparency, which is something that is very close to simplicity.
And finally, before the president calls me to order, because I am already running out of time, there are some things that are unnecessary.

For example, I understand that it is very appealing and very attractive to public opinion to talk about transparency in the activities of the deputies, that it is known that they come to plenary sessions.
You already know that, Mr. Capato.
What happens in the committees is already known. If there is a record of all of them. These are acts accessible to all citizens.
Or the diets that are charged, as you know, Mr. Capato.
That is to say, it is perfectly possible for a citizen to have access to that information.

Therefore, I understand that it is very appealing to public opinion and very flattering to defend transparency, but I want you to know that transparency is about making things look the way they are. And when one contributes to making things not look the way they are, Mr. Capato, then we are not contributing to transparency.
Thank you for your generosity, Mr. President.

and shame for the inability of everyone, of our states, of the European Union and of the international community, first to prevent and then to put an end to the criminal aggression that we denounce.
Shame and indignation at so much lying, so much ambiguity, and so much empty talk.
Shame because we know exactly what is happening and we do not act with the necessary and required decisiveness and coherence.

what to do to ensure that it is implemented to the letter, as our association treaty with Israel, which provides for its suspension in the event of conduct such as that currently taking place, must be implemented to the letter.

Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, as we can see, the textile sector has been experiencing a major crisis in recent times, which has led to numerous company closures, relocations, and unemployment, all of which are concentrated precisely in regions specialized in this activity.

Given the current economic crisis situation, the European Commission should act swiftly alongside the Member States to mitigate the socio-economic effects of this restructuring, which is particularly dramatic for the affected territories and families.

I think it is necessary to provide assistance to workers in the textile and garment sector with social measures, with plans for companies that are undergoing restructuring and are currently in serious trouble.
it would be desirable to allocate a substantial portion of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the restructuring and requalification of the textile sector.
This is particularly true for small and medium-sized enterprises, which make up the majority of the sector in the European Union and are most affected by the effects of market liberalization.
On the other hand, it is necessary to re-establish the control system for imports from abroad, and especially, due to their volume, from China.
It is not at all about promoting trade barriers,

It is about compensating for the negative effects of such an important transformation. And we must also not forget that the European Union is the world's second largest exporter of textile products and garments.

This makes it necessary to ensure the best conditions of access to third-country markets that are essential for the future of the textile and clothing industry based in the European Union, and especially for SMEs.
All of this, of course, always ensuring fair competition based on the promotion of environmental and social standards in these countries.

In this sense, the publication of correct information to the consumer, for example, with the regulation on the Made In indication, which to the best of our knowledge has not been implemented, would be of great utility, since
among other things, it would involve subjecting imported products to the same safety and consumer protection requirements as those manufactured within the European Union.

Mr President, in the EU there are various cases of languages of historical European peoples which, because they are not constituted as a state, are not allowed to be used in the debates of this Parliament. And this is a democratic and representative deficit.

One of these cases is that of the Basque language, Euskera, which is not a minority language but an official one, at least in the southern part of the Basque Country, which administratively falls within the Spanish state.

But the same does not happen, and do not take it personally, Commissioner, with the Basque Country of the North, which is part of the French State, whose president, before the UN Assembly, states that denying respect for national identities and languages is fueling humiliation and that without that respect there will be no peace in the world.
And then, neither Basque, Corsican, Breton, nor Occitan have the slightest official consideration or support to respect or encourage their use.

Therefore, I ask that the Fundamental Rights Agency monitor and work to ensure that within the member states, the mother tongue rights of no European people are violated, nor are their inhabitants discriminated against, and that all of them are considered official within their respective territories.
It is that rich man, Jaume Andreoc, welds guncha gaitic, Europe's hidden desire.

Thank you, Madam President. First of all, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Claudio Fava, for his great work in reaching a common position with the Council, which includes many improvements proposed by our House.
With this directive, we demonstrate once again our commitment to building a common migration policy based on a global approach.
The approach of this directive is clear: to fight against mafias, punish unscrupulous employers, and protect exploited immigrants who have no social protection.
We want the unjust poverty wages for immigrants to disappear, which also depress average wages, especially in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service, and hospitality.
These measures require great courage and political will, as there are many vested interests and a lot of money circulating in the underground economy.
Precisely in difficult times, it is more important than ever to manage migratory flows intelligently, with generosity but also with responsibility.
The easy thing would be to fall into the temptation of not trying to tackle the underground economy.
We cannot look the other way and leave some eight million irregular immigrants in a state of helplessness with working conditions akin to slavery.

Ladies and gentlemen, if we want this directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic and even criminal penalties are necessary in the most aggravated cases, which have a deterrent effect on employers.
This will help us reduce the informal economy and cut off the incentive for migration that is generated by the possibility of working irregularly.
It should be clear that the only option for working in Europe is the legal route.

That is why we want to move forward with the global approach and we ask the Commission, Commissioner, Mr Baró, to present the new blue cards, as soon as possible, for the other occupational categories.
Dear colleagues, Mrs Ferrero Balner, Mr Solana, I would first of all like to thank the three rapporteurs for their work and, as shadow rapporteur for the report on the CFSP, I will refer to
To this particular report, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr. Sarisbolski on the outcome of his work and on the collaboration offered by the other groups to achieve a consensus result.

Just as this Parliament has repeatedly called for the European Union to equip itself with the necessary instruments to speak with a single voice in the world, the House itself has also shown itself to be cohesive in evaluating and promoting the major priorities in foreign policy and common security.

The efforts of our group, the Socialist Group, have gone in two directions. On the one hand, introducing or reinforcing major issues that are key to us in a transversal manner throughout all foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of the

peace throughout the planet or a commitment to human development. On the other hand, proposing elements of rebalancing between the geographical priorities of the CFSP with respect to how they originally appeared in the text, if they appeared at all, or introducing them as a new element if they were absent.
In this way, we have advocated, for example, for greater clarification of the relationships between the institutional and cooperation frameworks involved in the recently defined Eastern dimension.

We have advocated for greater diversification and greater relevance in relations with Africa, a continent that we often only remember when wars of particular virulence occur, and even then, not always.

With regard to Latin America, we have wanted to reflect the current negotiation processes for association agreements, the first of a bioregional nature that the European Union will conclude in its entire history.

As for the Mediterranean, we have opposed a reductionist approach that only talks about security, and instead have included the entire rich political, economic, and sociocultural heritage contained in the Barcelona Process.

As for the amendments for the plenary, our group has not submitted any, believing that this somehow reinforces the balance achieved with the compromises, and therefore, we will oppose most of the amendments so as not to weaken the compromise reached in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. The Venezuelan referendum has ended with a victory for the "yes" side, elegantly acknowledged by the democratic opposition.

It is no less true that there has been no equality of opportunity in the campaign and that the ruling party has had the overwhelming support of the entire state apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even under these conditions, the country has been practically divided into two halves, and it will be very difficult to build the future with only one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion, and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not with visceral attitudes, disqualifications or insults that we will help Venezuela find its democratic, pluralist and free path.

In that sense, we criticize the Venezuelan government's decision to expel a Spanish Member of the European Parliament and even more so the way in which the expulsion was carried out. But we call on this House to avoid...

that our representatives make statements during their visit to third countries that violate the local legislation in force and even less so that they insult a head of state, even if the latter is open to criticism.
With these attitudes, we are compromising future missions of the European Parliament to other countries.
Mr. President, I have just returned from Venezuela, where I was invited by your electoral authority as a member of an international electoral observation group for the referendum held on the 15th.

The European members of that group have submitted a report to the National Electoral Council with an overall positive assessment of the process in terms of its organization, transparency, participation, free and secret exercise of the right to vote, and security in all its phases.

Regarding the statements made by Deputy Herrero to a Venezuelan television station, he noted that "they come to delegitimize the ongoing electoral process, make serious accusations against democratic institutions in that country, and border on interference in the internal politics of a sovereign nation."
Our Parliament should not encourage any kind of confrontation with the democratic institutions of Venezuela.
On the contrary, it would be up to the honorable deputy to provide explanations to this House about an action that affects us all.
The Budget Committee believes that it is of utmost importance to clearly define each of the budgetary instruments.
Therefore, the most realistic option seems to be the creation of a new instrument for actions other than public development aid for countries that fall within the scope of the regulation.
From a budgetary point of view, the proposal for funding from the Development Committee does not seem appropriate, as that money does not exist, even
count those lines with a multi-year allocated credit amount. There is a credit for 2009, but not for beyond.
In any case, since the funding for this new cooperation instrument must be compatible with the 2007-2013 financial framework, it is advisable to reverse it.
remember the importance of the mid-term review of the financial framework, which should allow for an adjustment of the ceilings for the various headings.
Well, at this late hour on Monday, the Commission will probably have other things to worry about more than this report.
Ultimately, what we are doing is nothing more than responding to a Commission report, a report on the implementation of Regulation 1206-2001 of the
Council Recommendation of 28 May 2001 concerning cooperation between the courts of the Member States in the taking of evidence in civil or commercial matters.
We are in a field that is truly not communal; it is an intergovernmental field, in which the Council has attempted to stimulate cooperation between these judicial bodies through regulation.
But in doing so, I believe there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union,

...that is, certain measures have been provided for......for example, the issuance of practical guides......the use of electronic media......etc., but I recognize that it is quite difficult......for the Commission to take action...

I don't know what the Commission has achieved or plans to achieve, but it seems quite difficult to achieve it because of the enormous difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation represents.

In other words, we are asking judicial authorities who collaborate with each other, we are talking about 27 countries, judicial authorities who handle 22 different languages, with very different legal systems, and we are trying to achieve results.
The Commission has found that the results are not good, that there is a huge delay in these cooperation mechanisms and, of course, that we do not have the means to do so.
Ideally, we would have the necessary material resources,
For example, what could the Commission do to equip judicial bodies, especially those at a lower level, with technological elements, such as a videoconferencing system?
Videoconferencing may be a utopia for many small courts across the European Union, but it seems to be the only way to do it.
I believe that the European Union should rely on existing institutions, specifically the European judicial network,
we would have to strengthen this institution so that the judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, any kind of training for judges is fundamental.
This is something that the Commission cannot do on its own either.
but the Commission can indeed encourage the development of this type of training course in Community law and knowledge of the different legal systems.
Then there is a huge difficulty which is the problem of languages, that is, how can a Spanish judge communicate with a Finnish judge with two such different languages.
Judges cannot be expected to have knowledge of these kinds of things, in addition to having to deal with their own law, which is complex enough on its own.
What can we do from a practical standpoint to facilitate the task of interpretation and translation for judges?
What could we do to help them do it?
in presenting this report, show no rigor or harshness towards the Commission.
I think the work is quite difficult.
What I would like to know, taking advantage of the fact that we have a commissioner here who is interested in this topic, is what the commission thinks can be done to provide a better response?
This 2001 regulation is somewhat imprecise, somewhat voluntary, and I'm not sure if, from a practical standpoint, it can have any consequences or if progress can be made with it.
Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislative term with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I recall that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we suffered a major maritime accident, the Erika shipwreck, off the French coast, which gave its name to an initial set of legislative proposals aimed at preventing and avoiding accidents.

We thought we had already averted the danger, but shortly afterwards the coasts of Galicia were ruined by the oil slick from another accident, even bigger than the first one, the one involving the personnel vessel.

Since then, in the Transport Committee, we have worked on successive legislative packages, trying to overcome the many resistances we encountered from shipowners, oil companies, classification societies, and also from certain Member States that rejected our proposals because they considered them too demanding.

Over these ten years, we have approved various directives and regulations, some of which we have had to revise because, due to the cuts made by the Council, they were not effective in their initial wording.

We approved the regulations for the introduction of double-hull ships, the European Fund for Major Oil Pollution Incidents, and safe havens. And now we are reviewing and approving the liability of passenger carriers by sea, investigating the issues.

maritime accidents, the Community system for monitoring and information on maritime traffic, port State control and finally the regulation and directive concerning ship inspection and survey organizations.
And it is good and desirable that all this can come into force and be applied by all the Member States in the shortest possible time.
That is why I feel satisfied.
But the legislative term is ending, I am leaving Parliament, and I am going away with the regret of not having succeeded in making the introduction of existing control systems mandatory.
are patented to determine when and how much waste from ships and fuel tanks has been illegally dumped into the sea by a particular vessel.
In other words, a kind of black box or tachograph that can be inspected by maritime authorities every time a ship arrives in port.

I believe we owe the marine environment better attention and more stringent procedures to address the pollution we produce, and if we don't, it will affect our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I trust that it will not take another 10 years to control illegal marine spills more effectively and efficiently.
President, the review of the Noviñeta Directive is a matter of great importance that concerns and worries us all, especially the peripheral countries, who feel they are the victims of this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to address the internationalization of external costs of road transport by attributing three new costs: air pollution, noise pollution, and congestion.

While the principles that inspire the proposal, that the user pays and the polluter pays, are reasonable, the proposed solution is not, in any way, reasonable, as it will be discriminatory for a sector that has been suffering the disastrous effects of the economic crisis for months.
Demonizing road freight transport, even if that was not the goal, has turned out to be the outcome.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is untimely and far from achieving the expected goals of sustainable transport, it would be a death sentence for a large number of small and medium-sized European enterprises that employ thousands of people.

people in the European Union who contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that products reach their final consumer. A consumer who will see how their products become more expensive due to the application of these rates.
Ladies and gentlemen, we need a competitive, sustainable, and environmentally friendly transportation system, without neglecting the road, because at present it is the only way to reach everywhere.
Modal shift remains a dream, far from being a reality.
Trans-European networks, motorways of the sea, cross-border connections are still in some cases projects and not a reality.
Ladies and gentlemen, when the titanic of the global economy sinks, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to keep playing, much less for joy.

On July 15, 2008, the European Commission adopted a communication addressed to the Council and Parliament recommending the establishment of a strategic partnership between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European Council on Foreign Relations recognized Mexico as a strategic partner on October 13, pending the Parliament's opinion on the matter.
Let us recall that as early as the seventh meeting of the European Union-Mexico Joint Parliamentary Committee, held at the end of October last year, we said that a
The strategic partnership between Mexico and the European Union is a necessary boost to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We note the good state of relations between both parties and the positive assessment of the current global agreement.

We insist on the need for our respective executives to strengthen collaboration in political, economic, and cooperative matters, especially in the face of new challenges of all kinds arising from the financial and economic crisis that is shaking our continents.

With the great country that is Mexico, we share values and objectives such as the development of democratic forms of government, commitment to gender equity, the consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and respect for human rights.

We advocate for strengthening cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug trafficking based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
As a result, we will support the proposal for recommendations on the European Union-Mexico Strategic Association, which will be submitted to Parliament this very morning.
I would like, with regard to the report on microcredit, to congratulate all the rapporteurs because they have done a great job.
has undoubtedly improved the Commission's initiative
And I understand that the recommendations set out here will allow us to establish a foundation for developing a genuine framework in the European Union for the microcredit sector.
which has been a success in many developing countries, including some in Europe, both as a mechanism for economic activity and as a tool for improving social inclusion and job creation.
but it had not been transferred to the sector or the community context. And I believe this is an opportunity to do so, especially starting from the economic and financial context in which we are.
priority in this regard is to strengthen the initiatives being promoted here, but more steps need to be taken.
The funds available for this microcredit support structure need to be increased.
We need to facilitate availability for people and businesses that do not have access to loans and in that regard I would like to highlight, Madam President, the example of the...
the European guarantee for microcredit loans as an instrument that can facilitate such access and that should be included in the report.
And I end up thinking that this will undoubtedly lay the foundations for us to create a harmonious framework in the European context that will boost the microcredit sector.

Madam President, taking advantage of the fact that we are discussing the budget, I understand that we must prepare ourselves for the negotiation next year of the continuation of aid to coal, an essential indigenous energy source.
And I say this well in advance because, inappropriately, some high-ranking official, confusing public opinion, allowed themselves to express an opposing view, leaking it to an economic publication.
None of that
Support for coal in my country must continue after 2012, and I want this to be recorded in the minutes.
Limit yourselves, gentlemen officials, to complying with the current plan and then, starting in 2012, with the instrument that we will begin to negotiate with the sector next year.
Thank you, Mr President. Commissioner, this question, as Mr Bocland has explained, is very timely, given the diplomatic conference on the ship recycling convention to be held in May.
That is why I want to congratulate Mr Bloch, not only for the question, but also for the resolution he has prepared.

In the Popular Party, we are in favor of the fight against the bad practices and methods that have been used to lighten ships and, therefore, we support Mr. Brokland's motion for a resolution. But there are some points that concern us.

The first is section 3, which he has also pointed out, which states that ships as a whole should be considered hazardous waste and, as a consequence, should fall within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have tabled an amendment on this point because there are different interpretations within and outside the European Union, and we believe that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and not contradicted, but it should be the future international agreement on ship scrapping that defines the details of its implementation.
The motion for a resolution also calls in point 14 for a financing mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

We think it is really a bit premature to talk about mandatory contributions at this point when the IMO has not yet decided on the system to be adopted for this funding. And I don't think the European Commission has a clear answer on this issue either.
Finally, point 15 urges the commission to clearly establish that the state with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible state.
we believe that it is the Commission's responsibility to decide this, which should also be decided in an international agreement.

The important thing is to ensure consistency between the future convention on ship recycling and the Basel Convention on the control of transboundary movements of hazardous wastes and their disposal, taking into account not only the Basel Convention, but all existing legislation.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, the first thing I would like to do is congratulate the rapporteur, with whom we have a great deal of agreement regarding this program, and congratulate all of us because in times of economic crisis, it is essential to maintain a program like this with clear positive social effects.

Although we are dealing with a consultation procedure from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that in these times of economic uncertainty, we in Brussels and Strasbourg are not exclusively concerned or

We are not only concerned about a recovery of the financial system, but we are fully aware that social policies, especially those that support those who need it most, the poorest in the European Union, must grow.

This food distribution program must continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy. Here we agree with the committee. Not only because European agriculture has a strong social character, because it is an instrument that works, because it is needed now more than ever and because it must continue to function.

In the Socialist Group, like the rapporteur, we are opposed to this program being cofinanced between the European Union and the Member States, as this would lead to discrimination between states based on their wealth, and it could happen that the program cannot be implemented in the most needy countries.

It is not understood that now, when it is most needed, the Commission wants to save Community money in the most social aspect of the CAP, especially considering that there are budget surpluses in the agricultural budget every year.
Full Community funding is essential for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries, especially the most needy ones.
43 million potential beneficiaries of this program demand a greater effort from us and, in no case, any budget cuts.
Austerity yes, but not for the poorest.
And it is precisely to ensure that it reaches the citizen of all Member States that the programme must cover the entire journey of the food distributed.

Therefore, the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, has submitted an amendment so that all expenses derived from distribution, including those of transportation, storage, and administrative costs, are covered by Community funds.
We also agree with the rapporteur that food should preferably be Community-produced and of high quality.
It is a position consistent with that maintained by this Parliament in other similar programs that we recently discussed in this Chamber, such as the fruit distribution plan in schools.
That's all and thank you very much.

We hope that the Commission will take into account the position of this Parliament when the vote takes place and, above all, that the plan will be implemented in the European Union as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile regions on our planet.
the consequences of unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic not only for the immediate environment and the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The thawing of large areas has brought these risks to the forefront, making it necessary to establish new global regulations to protect the Arctic, similar to those already in place for the Antarctic, while taking into account the differences that have already been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty between all the parties involved, including the European Union, is necessary to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable nature of human activities of all kinds, and multilaterally regulate navigation through the new maritime routes that are becoming accessible.
The Arctic Council, during its several years of existence, has been a model of cooperation to manage common problems.

In these times of difficulty and uncertainty, we must raise that spirit and that harmony to higher levels in order to prevent the states in the region or other international actors from engaging in geostrategic conflicts, forgetting what should be the common goal: the preservation of a great shared heritage.
Mr President, unlike the two speakers who have just preceded me, I agree with most of the speakers.
This is a good directive, an excellent directive, aimed at protecting interpreters.
When people talk about seeking a smarter model for doing business, what they're really talking about is putting an end to intellectual property.
because you can only do business if there is an established right.
We already have an established right at the national level...
The Commission, under Mr. Macrivi's leadership, has taken a courageous initiative, a positive initiative, and I believe the House should approve the compromise we have
achieved within the Committee on Legal Affairs thanks to the work of the rapporteur, Mr Crowley, and the various shadow rapporteurs, such as Mrs McGill and Mr Tubongo.
I think it is a magnificent directive, one that will promote the creation of intellectual property.
And in addition, the directive includes a few recommendations regarding the continuation of the work.

I believe that the approval by this House of that report, and I hope that the Council will align itself with the lines of the Council, the Commission and Parliament, will serve so that in the next legislature the

The Commission should continue along this path, make proposals to Parliament, and move forward in the area of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a great institution based on a common culture.

Yes, Mr. President, the information you give me is correct, but the impression we European parliamentarians and, ultimately, European citizens have is that we have a very dangerous loophole in Community law.
At the moment, as tax requirements are being reinforced in each of the member states, mobility is almost impossible.
And when we asked the Commission, the reason for the pragmatic approach is that the Commission never finds support in the Council.

We are in a kind of vicious circle where the Commission refers us to the Council and the Council refers us back to the Commission. But in the meantime, the reality is that citizens living in this Europe we want to build do not have the opportunity to live in different countries or establish relationships as a result of the heavy tax burden that can arise from the lack of fiscal harmonization.
fiscal. Can the Council do something to help us break out of this vicious circle?
Madam President, for once I am glad that the titular holder is not here, that Mr Tajani has come, because Mr Tajani has the advantage of having been a European parliamentarian.
And as a European parliamentarian, I know that you have experienced the frustration that we European parliamentarians have with regard to the application of Community law.

Now, in Parliament we tend to pick on the Commission. I think we are asking the Commission an impossible task, because all Community law and all the application of Community law is based on indirect application.

That is, the Commission has only a few officials at its headquarters where some complaints reach it and it has some possibilities for action. But at the moment, there is also a tendency to limit budgetary powers, so the Commission will not have the possibility to do so.
All Community law, all the application of Community law, is based on the actions of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, national officials.
And in this respect, I don't think we can demand too much from the Commission.
What we need to do is help the Commission. And I believe that in Mrs. Frazzoni's report there are some points that can be useful for achieving this application.
I am referring to those relating to the correlation of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments and the action of national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, on a mission led by my colleague, my group colleague present here, Marían, I had the opportunity to visit.
and to be present in this court and to be aware of the immense work that this court was carrying out, not only for Sierra Leone, but for all of humanity.
The Special Court for Sierra Leone, as has already been mentioned here, has certainly set a precedent.

A precedent because, as the resolution rightly points out, it is the first international court funded by voluntary contributions, the first court to be established in the country where the alleged crimes took place, and also the first court, as already mentioned, in which a former prime minister has been tried.

For all these reasons, not only because it sets a precedent, but also because it serves as a reference for other courts that have been established under its influence, such as those in Rwanda, the former Yugoslavia, Cambodia, and Lebanon, we consider it essential that this resolution be approved, on which we have been working together with the court for several months now.
Two years ago we passed a resolution to support its funding. Two years ago the court was going through a difficult period in which it was running out of decisions.
...and it did not have sufficient support. We must also thank the European Commission here... for coming to the support, let's say, financial, of this court.

Now we are asking for two things above all. First, that the convicted individuals serve their sentences. At stake is not just the functioning of the court that will end next year, but the legacy that this court will leave us. And secondly, obviously, all of this must be accompanied by increased funding.
In short, the Special Court for Sierra Leone is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have tried war crimes.

It is an example and a reference, and it is a lesson that the second poorest country on this planet is giving us, in which, upon entering the courthouse, we saw a motto written that said, "Without justice, there is no peace."
And precisely for that reason we have a moral obligation, not only as Europeans, but as human beings, to ensure that the legacy of this tribunal remains permanent in history.

Yes, thank you, Mr. President. I will be brief, as you will appreciate at this hour. Mr. Vice Chairman of the Committee, thank you very much once again, because you have demonstrated, as you did in the third package...

that their drive, their political category has been able to push for an agreement close to the Council and make it possible for the Parliament, Council and Commission to reach an agreement at this meeting and in these coming days as the legislative term comes to an end.
I think we should congratulate ourselves.
I certainly appreciate the close collaboration of the opinion speakers, both in the jury committee and in the environmental committee.

I appreciate and reiterate the work and collaboration of the shadow rapporteurs and, ultimately, I believe that tomorrow we will adopt a first-reading agreement on such an important regulation, which undoubtedly complements the work of Parliament.

The third maritime package is a success for this Parliament and for the European Union in all three institutions and once again justifies the codecision procedure, which is useful and allows for constructive dialogue in the interests of all European Union citizens.
I'm a minute late. Before I begin, I want to respond to the Commissioner, who knows about my friendship and affection for her, and indeed my friendship and affection for Mr. Orbán.
But the commissioner has not said a single word about the ombudsman's recommendation.
That is, the village representative who is familiar with all the arguments provided by the Commissioner has made a precise recommendation that the committee seems to ignore in all its aspects.

I don't even want Mrs. Cuneva to answer me because obviously she is not the one who has the data. But all the data she has given me is in line with what we knew and what the Ombudsman also knows. And she doesn't tell us whether in fact...

Despite all of that, and since the Ombudsman who is aware of this recommends that the rule be changed, he does not tell us whether the Commission will take on board what the Ombudsman is asking for and what Parliament recommends based on what the Ombudsman has requested.
Mr. President, I believe that the proposed regulations submitted to us by the committee are important and necessary, and on the other hand, it was also important and necessary that from the

The European Parliament insisted on the principles that have been emphasized by the two rapporteurs of the European Parliament, both Mr. Zivieska and Mr. Depré, and that is the principle of Community competence.

This is an issue of Community competence in which, for practical reasons, it is advisable to maintain certain powers of the States, but, as Mr. Barró said, these powers should be limited in scope and in time.
Community competence is unavailable and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor Parliament have the authority to renounce these community competences.

That being said, this is an exceptional procedure. I believe that the amendments we have discussed and presented, which I think will be approved by Parliament tomorrow, will allow for the approval of this package of measures at first reading.

But I also hope that, from now on, the Commission will be able to make progress in developing a genuine European private law, which is becoming increasingly necessary, as Mr Sogor pointed out, for example, in his last speech.
We are talking about the problems that directly affect people and to the extent that we are able to solve these problems, people will realize that the European Union has a role to play.

In conclusion, Mr President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Mr Debrey and Mr Esviesca, and thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to collaborate with us on this issue.

Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, I signed this resolution and asked to speak on this issue because I witnessed the so-called expulsion, which was actually the kidnapping of our colleague Luis Herrero.

And I was also able to confirm that political persecution, abuse of power by the Chavista regime, intimidation of opponents, threats, disregard for human dignity, and the trivial use of justice are all common practices in Venezuela, among other things.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the straw that broke the camel's back and led to this resolution. But there are thousands of cases as blatant as his that are cited in the resolution and others that are not cited.

such is the case of the Ocedeño son, who was born in the humble Caracas neighborhood of Petare, well known for its danger and also because it voted for a mayor who was not part of the Chavista regime.
Eligio studied thanks to the help of others, particularly Citibank, and managed to found his own business, Banco de Caracas. Moreover, he lived a normal life helping those most in need.
Today, however, he is illegally imprisoned in a Caracas jail, two years after being detained without any charges being filed.
Their only crime, being part of the economic oligarchy.
Another case is Niso Moreno, a student leader at the University of Los Andes, who was elected several times to the University Council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
He won the 2003 Federation elections, becoming the current Minister of the Interior and Justice. And this is his crime.
Today he is charged with attempted murder, lewd, violent acts, and all that despite having been exonerated of all charges.

Situations like yours are everyday life in this country where the persecution of opponents, with the intention of excluding them from political life and discouraging dissent, have become part of daily life.

However, from here it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy despite the difficulties. I am sure that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be deposed at the polls.
Madam President, Commissioner, it is indeed undeniable that progress has been made in recent times, but despite all the progress, the South of the Union is burning and is burning more and more.
That is why the resolution that this Parliament is going to pass cannot be just another resolution that serves to highlight the great concern that we feel about the misfortunes of others.
Wildfires occur for one reason or another, but no one can deny that they are fueled by climate change.

And regardless of the responsibilities that may exist in some states or autonomous communities, the fact is that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act swiftly and to put all the resources at its disposal, which are not few, to its disposal.
Neither the victims, nor the damage suffered, nor the need for reforestation understand bureaucracy, nor can they understand budget shortfalls.

We must prioritize and we must act. And acting is, in this case, modifying strategies, mobilizing resources, increasing them and coordinating preventive policies in an optimal manner, demanding when the time comes.

case of responsibilities to states that lack them. But assuming that this is not a problem of some southern European states and that climate change does not only affect some states, it affects everyone and is a common cause.
That is why one of the main tasks facing this Parliament in the near future must be to ensure that the European Union achieves clear commitments at the upcoming Copenhagen summit.
round to minimize greenhouse gas emissions as much as possible, because they are obviously at the root of the fires, of their causes, and these in turn are at the root of more climate change.
Therefore, approving this resolution is now the challenge for this Parliament, without a doubt.
But for that Commission challenge to be met, if you really, Commissioner, want to prevent the South of the Union, which does exist, from continuing to burn.
Mr President, thank you very much for giving me the floor. I am addressing Mr Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I have been following you with great interest and respect for a long time, ever since you were a leader in a country that is very close to us and very dear to us, which is Portugal.
I must tell you, however, that you have absolutely taken me by surprise now.

I am surprised for two reasons. Firstly, because you have shown contempt for the group in which I am present, the non-attached group, by not granting us even a minute of your time to come and tell us your political proposals.
We represent many European citizens and you have shown contempt for all our constituents.
Secondly, because of the fragility of their political project, because of the poverty of their political proposals in the document "Political Guidelines for the Next Commission".
Proposals that do not even manage to incorporate what you have defended throughout your own term as President of the Commission.
I have been surprised in this regard that issues such as energy, which have been well handled throughout your term, are now being presented to us as part of your proposals for the next...

Commissioner, you ended your speech by telling us that there is a crisis in the dairy sector, but you began it by telling us that you had already taken all the necessary measures and that the situation was being resolved.
Look, to err is human, to correct is divine.
And that is a Spanish saying that could very well apply to the case at hand today.

The dairy sector has been suffering from one of the most serious crises in its history for months, and despite this, because you are unwilling to compromise, the European Commission and some governments, including my own, the Spanish government, refuse to back down from the decisions made during the CAP health check.
Such decisions were made without taking into account the fragility of this sector and in a market context very different from the one that emerged after that commitment was closed.
it feels as though the member states either did not want to or were unable to see the storm brewing at that time.
The reform quickly became outdated due to the significant shift in the market, a shift that demonstrates that the sector is entirely at the mercy of price volatility.

The fact that major producers like France and Germany, countries that achieved the largest increase in their national production quotas in absolute terms in that agreement, are now the ones calling for a review of the checkpoint decisions, is very thought-provoking.
In my view, the Member States were wrong and should have listened more carefully to the voices, including mine, that called for postponing any final decision on the future of the sector until 2011.
It's a shame they didn't listen to us.
Do it now.
Mr President, this Parliament is the palace of the chimera, it is the palace of dreams.
The Irish people, with their strong vote, gives us encouragement and strength to continue prospering and building a strong Europe and, above all, a federal Europe.
Only in this way would we deserve the title of legitimate heirs of the founding fathers of Europe, thanks to whose work we are all here today.

Mr President, having overcome the concerns generated by the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, it is time, in my opinion, to consider how to deal with nationalist attitudes in the future, which so hinder the construction of Europe.
My idea is that these obstacles cannot come free of charge.
With a clear head, it is time to think about the possible measures to be adopted in the coming days and years.
This modest MP wants a future Council President who is a man, or better yet, a woman, convinced of European federalism, who can handle the
who is in the Schengen area and who is identified with and committed to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. Thank you very much, Mr President.
That is, on behalf of the committee, I would have had nothing more to add but an amen, but I had already prepared a speech on behalf of the Socialist group.
The breakdown of constitutional order in Honduras ends two decades without coups in Latin America and sets a dangerous precedent for other countries, especially the weakest ones, such as Paraguay.
The European Parliament cannot and must not remain deaf and dumb in the face of such a violation of the rule of law.

Both the Council and the Commission have unequivocally condemned the coup, supporting President Arias' mediation in line with the position unanimously adopted by the OAS with the backing of the United Nations.

The self-proclaimed de facto president, Micheletti, has violated the recently reached agreements, mocking the international community and preventing the return, among other measures, of the legitimate president, Mr. Zelaya.

Under the current circumstances, the election of a new president in the elections scheduled for November 29 suffer from illegitimacy from the outset, and their results cannot and should not be recognized by the international community.

The European Parliament would make a serious mistake if it sent a delegation to observe the elections because this would be interpreted as an endorsement of the coup d'état. The OAS has already ruled out sending an observation mission to these elections.
This Parliament is characterized as a guarantor of freedom, democracy, the rule of law, and respect for human rights.
As Vaclav Havel said this morning, there cannot be two sets of weights or two measures.

We are all democrats here and, therefore, militants of freedom. And therefore, whether we are talking about Cuba, China, North Korea or now Honduras, our discourse must be firm in the face of freedom.
Let us not be blinded by our ideological preferences.
There are no right-wing or left-wing coup leaders or dictators, only freedom killers and oppressors.
Many of us fear that things in Honduras will not change and that a very dangerous precedent will have been set, and the doctrine of the good, temporary, and not too obvious coup will have triumphed.

I want to congratulate the members of the Committee on Budgets, and its chairman, Mr Leinen, for the work they have done to enable us to have a resolution like the one we have, which we must approve without hesitation.
we can settle for already talking about the fact that we have enough with sectoral agreements, because talking about a patchwork agreement is already admitting part of the failure.
We must go ahead and approve this resolution, which has three noble aspirations.
A more obvious one is to avoid climate change, with concrete proposals for reducing emissions and a commitment to funding, and aiming for a binding agreement, I mean, not a patchwork one.

And two latent aspirations. One, to start working sooner rather than later on establishing a common energy policy, just as we once created a common agricultural policy because it was necessary. And, of course, the aspiration to regain the trust of citizens in politics and politicians, which is something we don't have enough of in Europe.
In that sense, the success of the summit will be the success of the three aspirations.
That is why I encourage the acting president of the Council to continue with his optimism, to push and negotiate all he can to drag the others into this success.

I don't know if the rulers of this multipolar world want to be judged by history for not being able to reach a binding agreement. But I, as a deputy, and I believe all representatives of the peoples, cannot be judged by history for not having been able to achieve in Copenhagen the binding commitment we have to humanity to avoid climate change.

Today, there is no doubt about the European Union's commitment to the fight against terrorism, and thanks to the Stockholm Treaty, the Stockholm Programme, we will continue to make progress in this area of freedom, justice and security that is so necessary.

But in my view, this struggle has been based on mutual trust between the member states. However, it is high time, and with the possibilities offered by the Treaty of Lisbon, to harmonize national legislations in the direction of not prescribing terrorist crimes, which should be considered crimes against humanity.

The day this happens, no one in this Parliament or any other will defend terrorists, as has happened, is happening, and may continue to happen, causing consequent harm to the victims of terrorism, who see those who murdered their loved ones being treated as heroes, while they suffer in silence.
I therefore ask this Parliament to promote or adopt the European Charter of the Rights of Victims of Terrorism, based on the defense of human memory.

Thank you, Madam President. I would like to begin by congratulating Mrs McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role played by the CAP in addressing international food supply needs.

Now that the European Commission seems to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the Community budget, it must be said very loudly and very clearly that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food sufficiency should be. And in past decades it has been seen that without the CAP, food sufficiency is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Agriculture cannot therefore be compared to other sectors of the economy that are able to thrive in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union to be able to run his business, and the Union, in turn, needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and quality food to an increasingly demanding citizen.
I therefore believe that there should be a change of direction for the CAP, but it should not disappear.

To achieve this, it would be necessary to guarantee direct aid to farmers, in addition to reestablishing a policy of agricultural market management that provides greater price stability, which would benefit not only farmers, but also consumers and third countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practices to foster balanced relationships between the different agents in the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a fairer distribution of commercial margins.
In addition, a consumer information policy is needed for European consumers that emphasizes the efforts made by Community producers to comply with European Union environmental regulations.
environment, food safety and animal welfare, because Community producers have to compete with products from third countries where much lower standards apply for those imports.

And those producers from third countries prefer to export to the European Union rather than supply the markets in their own countries for a genuine matter of profitability, with the backing of WTO negotiations.
According to a United Nations report, in 2009 around 270,000 people have been victims of human trafficking in the European Union.

With these figures in hand, it is necessary that the European Union's action is primarily based on the protection of victims, with special attention to the situation of women and children, who are the most vulnerable.
We cannot continue to stand by indifferently to this theater, to this spectacle of sexual exploitation that is unfolding before our eyes.
That is why I fully support this Parliament's request for assistance to victims to be unconditional, more decisive, and for harsher penalties, as Mr Barrot has just told us.
That being said, I would like to ask the President and the Council to use all the European legislation at their disposal, both existing and future, to protect victims of human trafficking.

I believe that the proposal for a European Protection Order for Victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the debates on the Stockholm Programme and which has finally come to light, will be an effective instrument for combating these crimes.
