And I expect a firm commitment, as we have already seen, from the Spanish Presidency to ensure that this order provides victims with special protection measures that are effective throughout the European Union.

I hope that those of us who have the responsibility to act on the most serious problems in our society will provide a real and concrete response to this extremely serious problem of human trafficking, and that we will not just stop at empty words.
We truly owe it to all the victims.
Mr. Zapatero, for a Spaniard like myself, it is an honor to greet your presence here in your role as President-in-Office of the European Union.
There are many expectations and challenges in this period, and we certainly cannot fail to meet the expectations that have been created.
Let the public see that our renewed institutions are instruments capable of providing solutions to real problems.
The program outlined by your lordship knows that it is shared by us.
For the Popular Party of Spain, this is a matter of state, and we will support your lordship in everything that we see as common interests of Europe and that are important for Spain.
It is an ambitious program and one that we hope will be filled with content.

I would like for people to be able to see, in that album of the Spanish presidency - since it will surely be colorful and varied - that they see in each event a milestone on real issues that affect them.
The crisis hits economies and unemployment seems like a fifth horse of the apocalypse.
You have had the honesty to acknowledge that 20% of unemployment exists in Spain, but that does not incapacitate you.
...what I believe is that it forces us to collectively produce...a solution or a real problem that we all have to solve...
that is a real problem.
Time does not allow me to say many things, Mr. President.

But I do want to tell you that Spain has many challenges ahead. I believe, I am confident in Spain's capabilities as a nation. And I want to believe, and I am sure, that you will be up to the level of our country.

We cannot fail to meet these expectations at this hour for Europe. On the other hand, the globalized world, as you have so intelligently pointed out, is giving rise to new centers of power, and it is necessary for the European Union to play a more active and coherent role in defending its values and interests.
Otherwise, we run the risk of becoming irrelevant.
Finally, Mr. President, Spaniards do not accept that anyone should hand us the ability to make proposals.
We have that legitimacy.

What we also need to have is the humility to accept those pieces of advice that Don Quixote received from Sancho when he recommended humility in the daydreaming about governing the island of Barataria.
I am pleased to say that José Luis Zapatero has not ceased to surprise European women with measures of great innovation and progress.
Of course, the formation of a truly equal government and the courageous way in which it has brought the issues of gender equality and respect for others to the national and European agenda.
Mr President, I warmly congratulate you on your ambitious action programme, certainly against gender violence, which is a social scourge.
The creation of a European Observatory on Gender Violence is a cutting-edge proposal that European women support and applaud.
Mr President, on behalf of the Portuguese socialists, I wish you good luck.
you can count on our solidarity
women with shoes on.
Mr. President, thank you. On such a serious issue as terrorism, we should not wait for events to take action.
We should anticipate this, but we don't.
And unfortunately, we move forward through acts of terrorism, such as the failed attempt in Detroit, which today forces us to make decisions that ensure the security of air travel.
Debating body scanners at airports is a responsibility we cannot evade, ladies and gentlemen.
We cannot keep waiting because the terrorists do not wait.
Therefore, the committee must assure us as soon as possible that the dignity and privacy of individuals will be preserved and that there will be no negative effects on health.
Having guaranteed this, we must adopt decisions for the entire European Union,

And to those who fear that fundamental rights will be violated, I say that there is no higher right than the right to live. And those of us who love freedom above all else need to live in safety in order to feel truly free.
Mr President, I believe that this crisis is an opportunity to move forward with determination and conviction in the creation of a strong Europe.

In that strong Europe, it is likely that the expression "improve coordination" should be abandoned, as it makes everything dependent on the subjects to be coordinated and ultimately refers to paralysis and indefiniteness.
We know that the finances and public debts of European countries will suffer as long as there is no progress towards European financial integration and there are no Eurobond issues.

In any case, European institutions can already take concrete actions. I won't insist on the rhetoric of coordination. And there are, on the one hand, the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision and, on the other hand, the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision.
Good evening. I wanted to say that I have not come to this Parliament to applaud the newly enacted law on abortion in Spain.

What concerns me is human life, and I am concerned above all else, and I am here to defend women whose lives are in danger due to gender violence and to offer them a space in which they can live freely and safely.

The resolution of this Parliament, dated February 2, 2006, recommends that member states adopt a zero-tolerance attitude towards all forms of violence against women and take the necessary measures to ensure better protection for victims.
The Stockholm Programme, approved in this Chamber, established an area of freedom, justice and security for all European citizens and prioritised the fight against gender violence.

It reflected my request to the Spanish Presidency to promote a European Protection Order for Victims of Gender Violence during its term, to ensure that victims of these crimes have the same level of protection in all Member States.

In a Europe without borders, the fight against gender violence should also have no borders, and the member states should make an effort to harmonize their legislation so that the fight against mistreatment of women transcends the

legislative obstacles and in the end we could offer at least within the European Union, we could protect the lives of women and their children and we could, I therefore ask the Commission and the Council to do everything

It is necessary and everything that is in their power to ensure the success of this European Protection Order for Victims, which is a very effective instrument for combating the impunity of those who do not respect women's dignity or their right to live free and safe.

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy put an end to the ideals of the Cuban Revolution, which had such a profound impact and inspired so much hope among people all over the world, especially among the most brilliant international youth.
What characterizes, however, the dictatorship of the Castro brothers at this moment is the impiety towards political and prisoners of conscience, the impiety against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco the Moribund, with his mistreatment of political prisoners, whom he also considered common. His same obsessive contempt for exiles.
Castro ends up like Franco and all the enemies of freedom when they become entrenched in power.
But we must save lives and show solidarity with those who are struggling and suffering.
It is our obligation as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Thank you, Madam President. President of the Council, Commissioner, never again, never again let our silence become complicity with those who destroy freedoms.

Let us never again allow a person who was fighting for their rights and those of everyone else to die in a Cuban prison or any other place without our raising our voice loud and clear demanding their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a 42-year-old citizen, a black construction worker, who only asked for improved prison conditions, died after 86 days of hunger strike and 7 years in prison for demanding respect for human rights.
And during those seven years, he was mistreated, humiliated, and scorned by his jailers, amidst, it must be remembered, a thick silence from the international community.
Other prisoners and human rights activists in Cuba are now on hunger strike, such as psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

Your Excellency, the resolution that we are presenting today, debating today, and voting on tomorrow, and which I am representing on behalf of the Social Democratic Group, demands the release of all prisoners of conscience in Cuba.
they once again speak out in favor of a democratic transition and strict respect for fundamental human rights.
Let us not, for the moment, enter into a topic that divides us, whether or not the common position should be maintained.
Let's focus on the topic now of saving lives and human rights.
And we are talking about a period of calm reflection in which we seek common ground on issues related to future policy with Cuba.
But this text also has an important added value.
The fact that six political groups are presenting it expresses a new era of broad consensus in this House on the issue of human rights.

Let it never again be claimed that the European democratic right bends to the orders, so to speak, of Yankee imperialism. But let it also never again be said that the social democrats are complacent or are accomplices to the communist dictatorship.
Simply because both statements are false, and the victims of the freedom killers wherever they are must know that they will find us united in the unconditional defense of their cause.

Mr President, I would finally like to thank Mr Salafranca, who negotiated this text on behalf of the European People's Party, Mrs Weber of the Alliance of Democrats and Liberals Group, and Mr Rodríguez.

On behalf of the Green Group, to Mr. Karsutnik, of the conservatives and reformers, and to other colleagues who have participated in this difficult, complicated, but I hope successful effort tomorrow.

And finally, I would also like to thank the President of the Spanish Government and President-in-Office of the European Union, Mr. José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, for his encouragement and support in getting this resolution that we are debating today off the ground.
"History will absolve me" was the famous plea of a young lawyer who moved his people to tears.
History absolves him of the effect of his rebellion against tyranny and then against the American blockade.
But with the same emphatic judgment, this Parliament, which represents the greatest space of freedom and democracy in the world, condemns the dictatorship that
The people of Cuba suffer from the violation of human rights on the island, the impiety towards political prisoners, and the contempt for their exiled nationals.
The judgment of history is clear.
With this resolution, deputies of all ideologies, we stand by the Cubans who are fighting.
Every possible means must be used to prevent the brutal repression they are suffering, even by going beyond the paralyzing so-called common position.
I pay homage to the poet Raúl Rivero in the final verse of his Havana. Do not impose taxes on affection, emptiness, suffocation, bitterness.
The ruins of the homeland are safe.
Stay calm, comrades.
We're leaving now.
This week marked International Women's Day.
In this Parliament we had many posters in all the languages of the European Union saying that yes, violence against women can be ended.

Today we are talking about violence in Mexico and it seems normal to me to acknowledge that Mexican women, indigenous and non-indigenous, are the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the military or police, and even homicide.
Unfortunately, so far, the responses from Mexican authorities have been ineffective, which is why it is correct to speak of almost absolute impunity.
Our resolution calls on the Mexican government to combat femicides, a harsh but accurate term, when we see that almost all murders committed against women remain unpunished.
For example, in the State of Mexico, in the last four years, only 11% of the criminals who murdered nearly 700 women were convicted.
At the same time, it seems that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible that two indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, were sentenced to 21 years in prison and even
now more than three years in jail for kidnapping the girls during a market incident, six men from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
investigation. I hope the judge, who will decide in a week about the appeal in this case, realizes the ridiculousness and injustice of the situation. But violence against women starts in the family.

I hope that Mexican legislators will soon improve the General Law on Women's Access to a Life Free of Violence so that the types of violence and the mechanisms that make the rules operational are defined.
It would also be normal to establish that domestic violence and marital rape are criminal offenses.
Moreover, in order for Mexican society to change and reject violence against women, it is important that in schools this issue becomes a primary concern in the education of young people.
Madam President, the truth is that the first thing I would like to do this evening is to thank Mr. Escotá for his excellent willingness to negotiate this report.
It has been a real pleasure to work with him and with the other spokespersons of the parliamentary groups.

We are proud of the position that will be demonstrated in the vote tomorrow in this European Parliament and we are proud of a position like this that defends quality, that bets on development and the value of rural areas, not only as an environment.

not just mere testimonies of a traditional European culture, but as true agents generating wealth and employment. Employment that we so desperately need now in these times of economic crisis and dramatic employment levels in some member states.

We also appreciate the defence maintained by this European Parliament and the position already taken by the Committee on Agriculture, which has made it clear that it is committed to quality in its highest degree.
And at that maximum level, we are, of course, committed to maintaining that differentiation between designations of origin and protected geographical indications.
Of course we reject the idea of lowering quality and we want attention to be paid to, and value to be placed on, community production.
I welcome Commissioner Cholo's words
which was certainly a pleasure to listen to, hearing him talk about the commitment to the future of the European agricultural sector.
Of course we hope that he will listen to the voice of this Parliament that will be made clear tomorrow in that vote.

And, finally, we hope that it will never happen again that the European Commission gets ahead of this Parliament by prohibiting things such as, for example, the marketing standards for fruits and vegetables that have done so much damage to free competition in Europe.
We want market imbalances to be corrected and we also want to focus on quality, variety, food safety and an adequate quantity of production.
We also want community productions and the quality of these community agri-food productions to be defended in the World Trade Organization.
And for that, of course, we also have the work of Commissioner Cholos, because our European producers and consumers cannot continue to be defenseless.
Thank you, Mr. President. The Commissioner has spoken about the absurdity and obsolescence of the procedures.
Let us therefore be consistent.
We have missed too many opportunities, too many treaties, to introduce Community competence over European airspace.
But if we could not intervene as we should have in the sky, we did so in the skin of the earth.
for example, by monitoring passenger rights and also mediating or calling for a truce in the various collective conflicts in land transport,
No minimum services. Maximum services to all parties.
Thank you very much, Madam President.
The procedure, the electoral systems, the election of Members of the European Parliament present problems. That means, Madam President, that we need a uniform electoral procedure.

which was a mandate that was already in the Rome treaties. And that is why, the coordinators, and I want to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to everyone, but especially to Mr. Jauregui and Mr. Duff, have agreed on an appropriate amendment.

Tomorrow we will vote and I hope that this House will support it precisely so that we can resolve this issue, this question of a uniform electoral procedure advised to the European Parliament, in the near future.
I think that would eliminate this type of question.

In his speech, Mr. Traskowski spoke about the necessary representativeness of this Chamber. And this is a factor that most of the speakers, including Vice President Sefcovich, among others, have highlighted.
I agree, and we say so in the Article 1 report, that the 18 enter en bloc, because if it were not so, we would lose representativeness.

And in order for them to enter en bloc, in order to fulfill that act of political justice that is the Lisbon agreement, we must, Your Excellency, be pragmatic because a transitional and exceptional situation also requires transitional and exceptional solutions.

And that is why, I make no secret of it, I do not like the possibility of having deputies in this Chamber who have not been elected since the 2009 elections. I say this clearly in paragraph 2, but if I have to choose between that and not having any...

enter at 18 or seek a pragmatic solution and enter at 18 and therefore comply with the Lisbon agreement, I ask this House and hence my report, to opt for that transitional, pragmatic solution, but above all, Madam President, a fair one.
Thank you very much to all for your collaboration and for the interesting contributions you have made to this work.

As I was unable to do so on March 11, International Day of the Victims of Terrorism, I would like to pay them a well-deserved tribute today from this Parliament, recognizing the enormous sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to start working on a directive that protects the rights of victims of terrorism, who are always the great forgotten ones, and endure the humiliation of being unjustly equated with their executioners.
It is high time that these European institutions recognized the dignity of the victims of terrorism and helped them in their right to protection and justice, which should soon be translated into law.

that will honor all those who make it possible and that the first article will be that support for the victims of terrorism will be recognized as the right to justice and that no government will ever pay a political price.

I call on all those who can defend the victims to never forget that true peace is born from justice, and that is the only one that we who believe in justice should defend from Europe and from anywhere in the world.
It has been necessary, Mr. President, to face the abyss and the economic collapse for the heads of state and government to understand that the path is not one of more nationalism, but of more Europe.
Measures such as the decline of the veto right in the European Council or the seed of a European public treasure are circulating in this direction.
Finally, albeit belatedly, we have realized that we are all in the same boat and that it is futile to address individual situations, especially in an improvised manner.

But I wonder if this attitude is a parenthesis or, on the contrary, the beginning of a true European economic government. Because what we have in excess, dear colleagues, is governance and what we lack is authentic government, if we want to be faithful to the testament of the founding fathers.

That is why, from this Parliament, we must push for all those reforms that aim to strengthen Europe and make budgetary and fiscal discipline a reality, forgetting, of course, about nostalgic sovereignties.
Colleagues, strengthening the European Commission and strengthening this Parliament is the only correct recipe for building a Europe that would otherwise vanish like a fleeting shadow.
Thank you, Mr President. Commissioner, on behalf of the INTA Committee, I would like to thank Mrs Desarnet for her cooperation.
Today, more than ever, there is a need for unity around the Mediterranean, the strengthening of major projects, and institutional development.
Today, more than ever, it is necessary to find solutions to the exit from the crisis, to research, to climate change, to water, to new energy models, to sustainable development.

And to achieve this, it is necessary to promote and finalize commercial and economic relations in the region, with short-term and long-term measures. Free trade zone, elimination of tariff barriers, opening of the North-South and South-South market.
The Barcelona Summit, the Spanish Presidency, will provide the opportunity for a new commitment, a new situation, a new sharing of ideas, the democratization of economic and social solutions.
The Barcelona summit can put us in a position to lead the Mediterranean.
Thank you, Madam President. Among the trans-European transport corridors is the railway corridor known as the Mediterranean corridor.
It is a vital communication that will connect North Africa with Europe.
For Spain, this is vital because this axis is a priority, as it would connect Algeciras with Europe...
without excluding other priority routes, it would pass through Almería, Murcia, the Valencian Community and Catalonia.
And why? Commissioner Reding said so. She said there is greater economic activity and a high concentration of land transport.
This is one of the two conditions.
...the possibility opened up to communicate with various ports in the Mediterranean area...
We need to gain economic momentum, be competitive, as the commissioner also said, because more than 50% of Spanish exports are produced in this area.
Therefore, if we increase the topic of a strategic railway axis through the Mediterranean, we will increase greater competitiveness for Spain and greater competitiveness for Europe.
Thank you, Madam President. I would like to take this minute to congratulate the Spanish rotating presidency for the efforts it has made this semester to overcome the
common position with regard to Cuba and create a new type of relationship between the European Union and Cuba that naturally includes the defense of human rights as a priority issue.
That policy has not been crowned with success, basically due to the intransigence of the Cuban dictatorship, which began this presidency in January of this year.

This year, with the expulsion of the deputy who is speaking to you when he was trying to visit the island with all the visas and all the legality to concern himself with the human rights of the island.
But that policy, that new policy that the Spanish government undertook, will yield its results sooner rather than later.

Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, this is a regulation that is of paramount importance for consumers and for the agri-food industry, because it is not easy at all to achieve balanced labelling that contains all the essentials, but is not so exhaustive that it complicates the information.
This is a great report and the opponent should be congratulated for it.
I agree with her on the major issues relating to nutritional information and the controversial issue of profiles, especially considering that the Commission did not comply with the
commitment to establish these profiles, as well as their conditions of use, before January 19, 2009, as prescribed by regulation 19-24-2006.

There is one issue that concerns me, and that is the possibility of the coexistence of national rules for labeling, because it goes against the objective of the legislation, which is harmonization and avoiding all possible obstacles to the functioning of a true single market.
Regarding the indication of the country of origin, current legislation stipulates that this information must be provided when, in the event that it is not indicated, it could mislead the consumer.
In addition, voluntary labeling is always expected to be available...
Going further may involve economic costs and administrative complexity for companies without providing any clear significant benefit to the consumer.
And regarding the use of different languages......I must say that the commission's proposal......coincides with the existing directive......which has worked well, which has not caused any problems...
And reopening this debate can be dangerous and necessary and cause problems for the producer's circulation.
Mr. President, the best evidence of our good will is the thousand amendments we are seeing from the committee to the plenary.

But in addition to good intentions, I believe we must be practical when it comes to labeling food if we do not want to achieve the opposite effect of what we are pursuing. That is, to confuse the consumer instead of helping them to inform themselves.
It's not about illustrating, but about preventing, about informing them about what they can eat and to what extent.
measure. We need to label about fats, about sugars, about trans fats,
Indeed.
...that effectively affects cholesterol......about all those substances that affect what we have said......about obesity and people's health...

Yes, but some other foods with some other information such as place of origin, when it does not lead to confusion, or for example in a piece of meat, that is, the place of birth, place of transit, place of grazing, the place of slaughter, can be very illustrative, but they will end up causing confusion.

It is up to us to be practical and ensure that this regulation remains one that will harmonize and inform consumers, or, alternatively, one that will cause more confusion and impose issues that, far from achieving better health standards, will result in greater degrees of confusion.

That's why I ask, for example, that some opt for the GDA, the daily intake amount, instead of the traffic lights. Because it's very clear that if you consume this amount or double it, you're going to get fat. Therefore, consume only one.
Daily intake amount versus other types of codes, is what some of us propose, so as not to further confuse the consumer.
Thank you very much, Mr. Martín Fragueiro, for being here on behalf of the Spanish Presidency in a report like this. Commissioner
Mr. Milana, congratulations on your ability to reach a common agreement and reconcile all interests, and to present an own-initiative report, one of the first own-initiative reports.
The take-off of aquaculture is important.

Health guarantees are important, sustainability is important, and the protection of the marine environment is important.
the image of aquaculture must be enhanced, and the scientific and research sector must also be strengthened.
Aquaculture is an opportunity, as Mr. Martín Fragueiro said, within the CFP, as the Commissioner said,

it must be given a coherent framework for coordination, it must be given the possibility of regularisation, because aquaculture can mean sufficiency, sustainability and economic resources, and I believe it is important for Europe.

Thank you, Mr President. In my view, this excellent report outlines the guiding principles that should inspire the new transport white paper that will shape European transport policy for the next ten years.

The present report has several milestones that are worth noting. The need for a financial fund as an essential instrument. The challenge of the growing demand for freight transport. The search for comodal solutions that

provide safety for users and goods. The urgent need for sufficient and safe rest areas in road transport. The diagnosis, in my opinion, is accurate: there should not be mere competition between the different modes of transport.

modes, but rather complement each other by seeking criteria of efficiency. The speaker's assertion, which I consider to be both courageous and fair, that rail or maritime transport is not always more environmentally friendly than road transport.

yours, Mr. President, a flawed approach.
Did you think you were really going to preside over Europe and influence the gears that make the complex European machinery run?
He even came to believe, because that's how people close to you let it be proclaimed, that the world would experience a stellar moment under his presidency.
None of this has come to fruition.
Let's go into some specifics.

In these six months of Spanish presidency, I would like to distinguish between the political direction of the presidency on one hand, and the work of the officials who have been working in the engine rooms on the other.
The first one has failed, and this is due to the absence of adequate impetus from the government presidency, which has been more of a back-and-forth affair.
However, I want to highlight the effort of the officials, their valuable willingness to serve Europe and Spain.
And the fact is, Mr. President, Spain has magnificent professional civil servants, and if there is something to be lamented, it is that they are too often sidelined in daily reality.
That being said, it should be acknowledged that some commendable initiatives have been adopted in these six months.
Among them, I am pleased to mention the organ donation and transplantation plan and the treatment given to patients' rights in cross-border healthcare.
The agreements on the new 2020 strategy and, above all, those concerning the European External Action Service, have remained more in the air, both still being too fragile.
What has happened with the European Protection Order for Victims of Gender-Based Violence has been lamentable, and the same bleak outcome has been offered by the
a basic Community patent for the survival of thousands of companies and partly blocked by the linguistic problems that Spanish legislation encourages.

But all the major political initiatives have ended in spectacular failure. From the Mediterranean summit to the European Union-United States summit, the latter of which was characterized by the fact that his own government was responsible for creating excessive expectations.
However, we must agree that the inability to implement its policy regarding Cuba has been highly positive for Cubans.
Finally, the progress made towards better European economic governance cannot in any way be attributed to his presidency, which has been conspicuously absent on the most relevant issues.
Farewell, then, to the Spanish presidency.

One positive conclusion I want to draw from this experience. My fantasy as a convinced Europeanist is excited to think that it could mean the end of rotating presidencies, as they have been conceived up to now.

This would be good news, because as long as Europe does not strengthen its common institutions, solidly uniting its fragments, it will continue to run the risk of being submerged in the void of irrelevance.
Mr President, believe me, Mr Zapatero, I would have liked to have delivered a different speech today.
Your lordship set up a semester full of ambition and set the bar so high in his aspirations that, when comparing it to what was actually achieved, disappointment is inevitable.
The fact is that his lordship has not been able to overcome a complex situation that required leadership and credibility.
Your Lordship has once remarked that the European Union is a club with rules, and I agree.
But it was his lordship who was responsible for demanding compliance with those rules.
The reality is that it was the Government of Spain to whom they were urgently demanding the fulfillment of its obligations.
In this picture, positive achievements that have not been lacking have been overshadowed.
Your lordship has had time to recount them, I have not.
Democracy, sir, is a regime of public opinion.
And that is what it appears to be. Obama's disdain, the cancellation of the Mediterranean summit, and the announced EU-US union constitute significant failures.
The rush to close improvised agreements at any cost has not enhanced the image of Spanish management. The way in which some respectable objectives have been achieved has been described as shoddy.
Spain is a great nation and will remain so despite the mismanagement of this time.
Our diplomats and officials have maintained their composure, and thanks to them, Spain's prestige will continue.
The truth is that the judgment of this presidency will be more influenced by the situation in Spain than by what I have or have not done here.
He could hardly lead such a difficult company, which has placed his country in a state of uncertainty and unease.
It's the best-case scenario. This presidency has sadly been irrelevant.
Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the coming months we will fully enter into the debate on the new CAP.

It is important to reach a good agreement, so I hope that the Belgian presidency will achieve what the Spanish presidency has not managed to do, namely to steer the discussions in such a way that the Member States commit to maintaining a policy in the future.

a truly strong common agricultural policy, with a sufficient budget to meet the needs of the 27 Member States, both new and old. And let us not repeat what happened in 2005, when there was a lack of money and modulation had to be invented.

The next reform of the CAP will determine the viability of a sector that not only provides intangible goods and services, such as environmental care, but should also ensure the supply of food to European citizens.

We have already witnessed painful situations of scarcity in the past, so it is necessary for the European Parliament to ensure security and supply based on community production, as the main objective of the next reform, without neglecting other contributions such as the fight against climate change.

Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, I agree with Commissioner Cholos that this report is necessary, very necessary, and comes at a good time, because it has demonstrated the abuses committed by large-scale distribution, which has severely disrupted the various links in the food chain.

The Bové report, which may at times go too far in its attempt to be overly interventionist, must be acknowledged from the perspective of a social market economy, such as the one advocated by the European People's Party, as it addresses the legitimate demands of European producers.

Moreover, it brings transparency to the different parts of the food chain, which is always a good thing, and gives much more scope and support for the weaker sectors of that chain to defend themselves and, of course, supports European consumers in learning more about that chain.

The European food industry could have been given more consideration in this report, perhaps, and that would have been very good. But this report also includes measures to curb price volatility, and that was very necessary.

Measures are also included to ensure fairness for these links in the chain, as requested by the Committee on the Environment. The text also calls for a fight against the abusive and unfair practices of large-scale distribution.
And it is high time to establish a list of abusive practices and for European legislation to strictly prohibit them.
It is also important to include measures to prevent unfair practices through white labels that are against competition and that violate intellectual property law.

For all these reasons, we must support the BOVE report and support all our colleagues from the various parliamentary committees, INCO, Environment and Agriculture, who have worked so hard to ensure that this report finally sees the light of day and helps European producers to get back on their feet.
the alarm bell rings and it's true
And there is also frustration, as can be heard in the speeches in this plenary session, for not having achieved the millennium goals.
And the truth is that what is at stake is very much.

Our natural environment is so fragile that if one day the big fish decided not to continue eating the small fish, we would all have to pay for it out of our generational pocket, with our health and well-being as the currency of exchange.
The European Union is a leader today in the fight against climate change and has been for some time in pioneering and conservation measures.

But as the unmet targets demonstrate, it seems as though there has been a lack of will, not only for implementation and coordination, which have also been mentioned here, but also for expansion, to go beyond our very limited special conservation areas.
Of course, biodiversity is not a museum piece that can be locked away in a ghetto area, as sometimes seems to be done, with a glance from time to time.
Biodiversity is alive and knows no borders. It crosses the entire earth with a domino effect in which if one piece falls, all the others fall.

And I draw attention to the need for a global and more community-based approach, especially with regard to soil, because subsidiarity as the sole method for managing soil or forests can be one of the new formidable enemies of biodiversity.

That is why I draw attention to paragraph 67 and the possible vote that will be cast, and I ask you to reject the second part, because I am convinced that a common policy on soil would help to conserve the entire territory.

so varied, so diverse for good and for bad, and so lacking in political will on the part of the states, and so in need of more and more European union, with all the implications of the word, more union also for the land.

Thank you, Mr President and Commissioner. First of all, I would like to highlight the work of the rapporteur, Mrs Macabena, not only in terms of content, but also in terms of form, because she has done it in collaboration with all the shadow rapporteurs.
We would also like to thank the experts from the Spanish Administration for their contribution to this agreement.

The purpose of this European Union pharmacovigilance system is to strengthen the monitoring, transparency, and communication of the safety of marketed drugs, especially in terms of their risk profiles and the adverse reactions they may produce.

It is worth noting the creation of the European Pharmacovigilance Committee, which will evaluate and issue recommendations to the European Medicines Agency regarding safety issues that may arise with medicines marketed in the European Union.
The solution reached for the notification to pharmacovigilance of suspected adverse reactions, both by the Member States and by the marketing authorisation holders, is very important.

...Eudra Vigilance will be the only source of information......but simultaneously the competent authority......of the Member State where the adverse reaction is suspected......to have occurred will be informed......and this is very important...
It is also worth noting the opportunity it provides consumers to report any adverse reactions, and in this regard, the agency's creation and management of an eco-portal.
The European Medicines Safety Portal, which in turn links to the portals of each Member State, will help to improve citizens' knowledge about the safety of the medicines they consume.
And, finally, we cannot forget that, since pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role in protecting public health, the approval of the directive and the
This directive and regulation will contribute significantly to this by improving not only the current procedures, but also the coordination of actions between the different Member States.
Thank you, Mr. President.

The recognition of sanctioning authority to suppliers, as well as the alternative resolution excluding mass exchanges as a possible infringement, make it impossible to vote in favor of either of the two reports in question.
The Galó report has aroused great interest and could have been timely, but the core of the debate is too heatedly centered around the argument for or against the French law called ASEC.
of cutting off internet access for offenders, without there having been a genuine European debate that takes into account the reality of other progress in national legislation.

I hope we will reach a common position within the Socialist group and a majority in the European Parliament in the debates and amendments on the Commission's proposed directive that will soon arrive in Parliament, as announced by Commissioner Barnier.
On that occasion, we will try to reach a more balanced position than today, one that takes into account both the rights of Internet users and the essential respect for intellectual property.
I congratulate those who have worked on this report, on this financial package, especially the officials and the Members of this Parliament.
A financial crisis of enormous proportions had to occur for Europe to wake up.
However, an opportunity has been missed in part to strengthen Europe's common institutions. Because, on the one hand, these new supervisory authorities have a scope of competence.
compared to similar authorities in Member States and it is also regrettable that no progress has been made towards similar integration to that which occurred with the central bank system
We have made progress, but we must continue to climb the mountain.

As a member of the Human Rights Commission, as a Spanish and European citizen, and as a victim of terrorism since the ETA terrorist organization murdered my brother and his wife in Seville, I am addressing this Parliament to denounce the Government of Venezuela and its president for allowing ETA terrorists to disappear.

...they are trained in Venezuelan sleep...  ...under the orders of the alleged terrorist Cubilla...  ...who works for the government of Hugo Chávez...  ...despite the fact that an international arrest warrant is out for him...  ...which is a serious violation...  ...of the fundamental right to security...  ...of any European citizen...
I demand that the Government of Spain take decisive action in the face of this grave humiliation of all Spaniards.
Zapatero cannot continue to remain silent while the Venezuelan ambassador calls our civil guards torturers, who have been and will be an example of bravery in the fight against ETA.
nor can we look the other way in the face of this growing cooperation between ETA and the FARC on Venezuelan soil, as Judge Eloy Velasco has already denounced.
Zapatero cannot shake hands with a leader like Chávez, who is turning Venezuela into a haven for terrorists.

The president of a country like Spain, where terrorism has caused so much pain, cannot continue to ignore this problem and should give a response, the one it deserves and the one that any ordinary citizen would give if they had the opportunity to do so.
On February 14, 2008, as a Valentine's Day gift, the Conference of Presidents decided that the intergroups would only meet on Thursdays.
Since then we have been trying to resolve this issue.
We haven't managed to do it.
The intergroups today, Mr. President, have to meet on a date that is not suitable...
they never have rooms and they never have interpretation.

Today, I speak not only as the president of the Poverty and Human Rights Intergroup, but also with the mandate of the majority of the intergroups in this House, and therefore, of the members of this House who are part of those intergroups.
And I solemnly request that the Conference of Presidents reconsider and overturn the decision of February 14, 2008, and return to the previous situation of freedom for the intergroups.
And if it does not, I also say politely that we will bring the matter to the plenary of this house and it will decide who in this house is sovereign, which is this Parliament.
Mr. President, on the International Day against Trafficking and Smuggling of Persons for the Purpose of Social Exploitation, some data was revealed that should make us act like reptiles.
More than 90% of prostitution in Europe is a result of blackmail and extortion.

And in light of these facts, we should ask ourselves whether we are doing everything necessary to protect the dignity and integrity of thousands of women whose rights are also protected by the Fundamental Charter that we approved with the Treaty of Lisbon.
Because we are not talking about the oldest profession in the world, but about the only form of slavery that we have not managed to eradicate from old Europe.
Countries like Spain are making significant efforts in this regard, pursuing traffickers, raising public awareness, and promoting rehabilitation programs for female victims.
But it is not enough.
Europe must be a single space of action and commitment.

The next directive on treatment is an opportunity to act on demand through pedagogy and to make it more difficult to access the facilities available, for example, in the offer to advertise in all types of media. In addition to increasing bilateral cooperation with third states to combat this scourge from its origins.
...we have an opportunity...
I draw the attention of this Parliament to continue being at the forefront of citizens' rights.
Thank you, Madam President. We all agree that the foreign service is a historic opportunity for European integration.

But to achieve this, it is necessary to act with a broad vision, because now is not the time for internal struggles over resources that are transferred or retained in the short term, or for wars between the different European institutions.
What is needed now, on the contrary, is to have an overall vision of what the European Union should be in the world. That is, to do exactly the opposite of what has been done in the past.
which happened a few days ago on the occasion of the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize, where too many voices were heard, not all of them courageous, coming from Europe.
