Mr. President, the regulation we are debating today is of vital importance for the future of a sector, that of cutlery and related products, which in my region, the land of Don Quixote, specifically in Albacete, represents, in addition to the survival of more than 8,000 jobs, an element of identity and a commitment to the future of craftsmanship as a source of employment.
And the Meidín seal on knives has long been advocated by social groups such as Aprecu and fought for by the Government of Castilla-La Mancha with the unanimous support of its regional Parliament.
A seal of origin that is not interventionism is a commitment to transparency in trade rules and the fight against fair competition.

It is about increasing consumers' decision-making capacity when choosing a product so that they take into account not only the final price of the product, but also the quality brand, the place of origin, or the social conditions under which it is produced.

And, above all, it will represent a new horizon of optimism for many people who are going through a tough time, but who today look at us thinking that we have not been indifferent when it comes to advocating for fairer trade, yes, but also for adding value to those who, in addition to producing, do so with respect for social rights and the best conditions for European workers.
That is why I am grateful to the opponent and to Mr. Menéndez del Valle for their political support and social awareness on this important issue for my land.
Thank you, Mr. President. Let's see if I can bring a bit of calm to this lively debate.
It is regrettable that some countries and some of the states that make up the European Union are still present at this G20 forum.
Despite this anomaly, which certainly weakens Europe's image in the world, it would be good if there were at least a common global position in that world forum.
And what would, in my opinion, be that common position?

In my humble opinion, first, the adoption of a comprehensive agreement to address the consequences of the crisis cannot be delayed, and not just a financial agreement. Second, Europe must maintain the euro as a reference currency or, if you prefer, as an anchor for the future.

avoid the turbulence in the markets from dragging us along and making us repeat the mistakes that were made throughout the 20th century. The euro, in third place, must serve as a herald of what Europe should represent in the world of democratic values and human freedoms.
public
In summary, it is important to know that in the global world, in this global game, those who only play national cards lose.
Thank you, Mr President. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we are in a position to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Meisner.
There were different positions, conflicting ones, and she has obtained compromise solutions that allow us all to be together on an important issue.
Ladies and gentlemen, the Transport Commission has decided that all bars should be protected in a similar manner, arguing that otherwise, an unfair competition situation would arise.

We accept the majority position in favor of a legal situation with uniform rules for the entire Union, but I will not spare this House from pointing out clearly that it also implies a certain lack of fairness.
It is evident that the Baltic Sea, the North Sea and the English Channel are more polluted areas and that controls on sulphur limit values will have to be more stringent in these cases.
The measures concerning ports should be positively evaluated in terms of their impact on solutions to reduce transportation times and handling costs.
In any case, I will not tire of reiterating that we still have work to do on this issue.
If a decisive liberalization of ports is not undertaken, they will not be able to expand the central role they are expected to play in the context of comodality.
Welcome also, ladies and gentlemen, the impetus of a strategy aimed at modifying the specific impacts of climate change on the city.
I think this is a positive report that we should vote for.
But we must not forget that it occurs in the context of a major disaster, that of the Gulf of Mexico.

And in this regard, the Commission is urged to assess whether the framework of the review of the regulation of the European Maritime Safety Agency is strengthened by the role that the Agency should play in the prevention inspections and subsequent tasks of cleaning up oil spills.
My personal judgment, Commissioner, is that yes, and that these tasks should be reinforced with the mandate that is required for this purpose.

Thank you, Mr. President. The integrated maritime policy is a cross-cutting, regional, and sectoral policy, which must include fisheries policy and agriculture, and it must not be subordinated to other policies.

We must all respond to environmental and economic problems, both to society in general and to the fishing industry. New technologies, fishing methods, species development, a plan for maritime economy.

for more employment, quality supplies, international relations that prevent piracy, and to promote the governance of our barrier-free seas, and not to have sustainability problems as in the case of Iceland.
This would be working towards an integrated maritime policy. This would be working towards the environment and sustainability.
Recently, the Church of Our Lady of Help was attacked in Baghdad, and 58 people were murdered, most of them women and children, simply because they were Christians.
Al-Qaeda has proudly claimed authorship of the feat.
It is not an isolated incident, but the culmination of persecutions and attacks on Christians in countries with a Muslim majority.
Expulsions in Morocco, threats in Turkey, attacks in India or Nigeria.
In January, six Christians were massacred at the door of a church in Cairo.
Cairo. How long will the complicit silence of Western democracies last?
Fortunately, President Buseca has made an institutional statement.
High Representative Mrs Ashton's statement of condemnation was limited to a condemnation of a terrorist act.
Why is the mobile phone not mentioned? The condition of being Christians is the unequivocal cause of the massacre.
I haven't heard anything from Mr. Zapatero. I haven't heard anything from President Erdogan.
What is the purpose of the Alliance of Civilizations?
I feel sorry for our foolishness and our cowardice.

Inevitably, the memory comes to mind of the lamented and misunderstood Oriana Fallaci, who announced the arrival of Eurabia and was almost stoned for having the courage to denounce what is happening in complex Europe.
Thank you also to the Commissioner. I share the desire of this House.
I want the proposals from the Europeans to get the support they deserve in Cancún.
In relation to this debate, it is important to emphasize the role of cities in environmental preservation.

There is an agreement between more than a thousand mayors of the European Union that demonstrates the existence of recognition of the problem by these authorities, whose actions are crucial if we want to succeed.
The grand words we use are of no use if we do not have the cooperation of the mayors of the cities.
It is therefore very important that emissions are disclosed, as cities produce almost 80% of greenhouse gases.
Today, there is no such disclosure, and, even worse, there is no common standard for measuring these emissions themselves.
There is a non-profit organization called the CO2 Disclosure Project that already hosts information from thousands of companies and that I think could also be used by municipalities.
Without their cooperation, without the cooperation of these municipalities and mayors, environmental action remains nothing but smoke, the very smoke we want to escape from.

Thank you, Mr. President. Some have said that the condemnation of Morocco is too lenient given the magnitude of the human rights repression in the Sahara, where Morocco is nothing more than an occupying country without sovereignty or any legal title.
But the important thing is the message that all of Europe and this Parliament can no longer tolerate his violence.
Yesterday I spoke about the Hague Tribunal in this very Parliament.

The international community that sadly failed to prevent genocide in Rwanda, Yugoslavia, and Darfur, I hope will prevent it in Western Sahara and that we will not have to see it before another court, also in The Hague as I said, but this time for war crimes.
President, Commissioner, the directive approved in 2009 was a success because it updates the regulatory framework that has been governing safety in toys.
It's a big step in the right direction because it shows us the way forward, but it's not enough.
We must always be vigilant and attentive to ensure that the toys being marketed do not endanger the safety and health of children.
All toys on the market must comply with current legislation.
We must review and improve the surveillance mechanisms to detect dangerous toys, whether due to substances considered toxic, CMR, fragrances, and other hazardous substances such as HPA compounds.
The rules to be followed need to be clearer about the warning regarding the minimum age and the dangers resulting from improper use.
The recommended age for toys must be based on studies of children's behavior.
We need to be able to adapt our regulations to scientific advances supported by solid studies and be more rigorous in market surveillance and the importation of toys.
It is necessary to work together and strengthen cooperation between member states and rely on the joint work of customs to control the route of imported toys.
Citizens are getting ready to do their holiday shopping, and we must give them the assurance that the products they buy meet all safety requirements.
that in this debate we have seen clearly that we all agree to support the objective of this report.
The different political groups have shown their support for this directive, which offers greater protection to victims.
Therefore, I wonder, what obstacle exists in approving this instrument?
I repeat, what fears are there that something so necessary and simple as protecting victims equally throughout Europe will finally become a reality?
Hoping that this Parliament will approve this report by a majority, I address the Council and the Commission, reminding them that we have
we have overcome the legal obstacles in our negotiations. And I applaud the Commission for recognizing our work, just as we recognize the work it will do in the future.

So we don't have to exclude ourselves, but rather help each other by approving this more concrete instrument today. Tomorrow, the commission will present a broader package of measures to help the victims, and I commit to collaborating with it.
Therefore, let us be brave and responsible today and help all those who have the right to live in a safer Europe.
Let's help everyone, I repeat, whether they are men, women or children.
Let us help those who are looking to us today for a better life, a life that will return their freedom, their security, and above all, their dignity.

Mr President, the Group of the European People's Party will vote enthusiastically in favour of this report, and I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteurs, the committee and the Council on this agreement.
We coined, ladies and gentlemen, the term "democratic deficit" in the 1980s.
With this, we meant that in the European Union, decisions were only made by the Council of Ministers on proposals from the Commission, and this Parliament was only consulted.
The battle of this Parliament since the 1980s, through the Maastricht Treaty, the Amsterdam Treaty, the Nice Treaty, the Constitutional Treaty, the Lisbon Treaty, has been...

fill that democratic deficit. And I believe that with the Treaty of Lisbon, with the new powers of the European Parliament, with the participation of national parliaments, we have achieved that objective.
And we rounded it off today with this citizens' legislative initiative, which was due to the good cooperation between national parliaments and the European Parliament during the Convention's work.
And I want to remember here the names of Jürgen Mayer, our German Social Democrat colleague, and Anand Lamassur, who brought that initiative to the plenary session of the convention and made it pass.
Therefore, I believe we have come full circle, Madam President.
I believe that today, when we vote on the initiative, we will have drawn up, put on the table, the death certificate of the concept of democratic deficit.
It is now up to us, ladies and gentlemen, to act responsibly. And today we also have the opportunity to do so.
By voting on the Union's budget, we will fulfill what is expected of us: a responsible Parliament and a Parliament that co-decides.
I believe it is a good day for Europe, ladies and gentlemen.
In January 2012, 400 Spanish egg producers could disappear, around 30% of the total in my country. With the loss of a production of 300,000 tons of eggs

And the European Union could stop producing those 80 million eggs, those 2 million tons, and we would only manage to have them covered by imports from third countries, whose animal welfare standards are much lower than those of the European Union, if we do not act with great intelligence.
This 1999 directive, which requires an increase in the space of laying hen cages, demands that we act intelligently and with a positive outlook, because if we don't...

we will only manage to weaken European production and give extra opportunities, commercial opportunities, to third countries where the space per bird is infinitely worse than the current space we have in the European Union.

It is a directive that requires a huge amount of effort from European producers. In Spain alone, we can understand that the cost increases to around 600 million euros. But we must also not forget that it has an economic impact that extends to the egg product industry and the food industry in general.

I therefore ask for the support of the honourable Members for the amendment proposed by the Popular Group to the second paragraph, which calls for a solution to be sought at least for the responsible farms, those run by responsible industrialists, which are in the process of transforming their farms and will have almost completed this by January 2012.

We must support them in transforming these facilities and give them time to complete this process, thus avoiding irreparable damage to the farms and preventing a sudden shortage in the community market, which would consequently increase prices for consumers.
It is about respecting the directive, giving the egg and egg product industry a chance, while also respecting the right to animal welfare and the right of consumers to a reasonable price.

Mr President, I believe it is only fair to thank the rapporteurs, especially Mrs Grosset and Mrs Dagmar Romberen from my own group, for the work they have done to get a regulation out of deadlock and make it useful, because this work has made it possible to include the right to public health as a legal basis.

and to have a new orientation that allows us to lay the foundations that will guarantee citizens the safety and quality they choose at any given moment. Above all because it also allows for a clear regulation of the role of the states, both those of origin that have to make the payment and those in which treatment is received.

But I believe that we should not be satisfied with that alone, but rather that this should be the beginning of a much greater advancement that makes, as Mrs. Romberen said, this directive a mere formality, because the level of equality achieved in all the states makes it unnecessary for each citizen to travel to each country.

And in that struggle, we must obtain a standard that guarantees citizens' rights more effectively in relation to the care they must receive, benefits, assimilation, and security, than the mere right they already have to mobility between states.
Equality is what will bring us together, and if not, we will be taking very small steps.
Madam President, the Spanish Socialist delegation has voted in favour, as has the rest of our group, but I would not leave here without expressing my concern that this directive includes...
the issue of organ transplants against the opinion of the Committee on the Environment as a result of the Council's persistent insistence on including transplants in this directive.

I hope that this inclusion does not diminish the effectiveness of the good legislation that we approved in this very plenary session, both with the Transplant Directive and the Action Plan, just a short time ago and with virtually unanimous support.

And I warn that we will be vigilant to ensure that this inclusion does not undermine the good work done by such successful organizations as the National Transplant Organization of Spain and, of course, with that intention of saving 20,000 lives that we had both in the transplant directive and in the Action Plan, which, I repeat, we approved here.
Therefore, I make it clear and say that we will continue to monitor compliance with this directive in that regard.
Mr President, today is also European Day against Sexual Health.
Ladies and gentlemen, the data is alarming. The World Health Organization estimates that more than 300 million people contract a sexually transmitted disease involuntarily each year.

In Europe, as the European Sexual Health Forum warns, there is a worrying increase in the number of unwanted pregnancies among teenagers due to an excessive lack of education and information among our young people.

Moreover, as the Commission points out, there are different and diverse inequalities in Europe regarding access to sexual health services, depending on the country and, within these countries, depending on the citizens' income level.
A European strategy is needed to combat all of this.
Only five member states have plans in this regard, but in all of them, the number of unwanted pregnancies, sexually transmitted disease infections, and also the number of abortions has been reduced.
A common strategy that focuses on prevention in the educational field, expands information policies, increases efforts in family planning, and facilitates accessibility to contraceptive methods.
A comprehensive and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to guarantee every citizen's right to sexual health under the safest and healthiest conditions.
At a time of strong social tensions, one cannot help but enthusiastically welcome the major social agreement in Spain between the government, trade unions, and employers' associations.
This agreement is exemplary for Europe, where such milestones have not been achieved for a long time.

The arguments of Cándido Méndez, one of the main protagonists of that Spanish pact, who attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels last Tuesday, February 8, are also very important to consider.
Cándido then insisted on the need to extend consultation on a European scale and on the need to have the voice and initiatives of trade unions in our Europe.
This is how it should be...

Thank you, Mr. President. Despite the differences in terms of terrorism and immigration, I have observed that the European Union unfortunately moves at the pace of emergency situations, such as a serious murder.

an attack or a massive landing of immigrants like the one currently happening in Lampedusa, where the exodus of citizens from Tunisia towards the Italian coasts could result in a chronicle of a death foretold.

The journey of hope can end in a cursed journey and will weigh on our consciences, on those of all those who witness these continuous uncontrolled flows and do not say enough is enough with sufficient authority.
When it happens, we'll put our hands over our heads, but the next day we'll forget.

European citizens have the obligation and the right to know the truth: that the Mediterranean strategy is not working, that the common immigration policy will remain a dream as long as European countries do not commit to sufficient financial resources to make the border effective.
Talking costs nothing, but we have to act.
Act. Do they really believe that Frontex can currently guarantee security at the European borders?
I don't think so.

And let's hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt and other Maghreb countries do not decide en masse to seek a better future in Europe, but rather to build it in their own countries, because that is what they have been fighting for, and we must help them.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but above all truth when speaking of a common European migration policy today more necessary than ever.

Madam President, it has already been said that the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and must continue to be the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that also reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is noteworthy that in OECD countries, the highest levels of equity in citizens' income are found in pensions, or that due to the crisis, private pensions lost 20% of their value in 2008 alone and are still, to this day, far from the required solvency levels.

All of this demonstrates that, at a time of unavoidable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be addressed in a cross-cutting manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies on birth rates or work-life balance.
ambitious policies on access to and retention in employment, or even immigration policies based on integration that also ensure, from a demographic point of view, the sustainability of our pensions.
Finally, I regret that the text does not set limits on the abuse of scholarship figures in companies, since, as a general rule, these are excluded from all types of social contributions.

In my opinion, this is essential for a whole new generation of workers who are being asked to do more to have a decent pension, and who should also be made to suffer less in order to access decent work.

President, Commissioner, we are at a key moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects, but also on territorial ones.
Territorial cohesion aims for harmonious development among territories so that their citizens can make the most of their territorial distinctiveness.
But in order to achieve this goal, it is also necessary to make progress in the area of cooperation between the regions of the Union that are facing the same challenges and problems.

This is the objective pursued by the European Union Strategy for the Atlantic Region. A common perspective to address the common challenges faced by the states in the region, including marine research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is in line with the 2020 Strategy and the European Union's policies for the period after 2013, especially with regional policy and maritime policy.
But, ladies and gentlemen, first and foremost, it is necessary for this strategy to be based on renewed multi-level governance, based on closer involvement of public authorities.
regional and local authorities, Member States, the European Union and private sector stakeholders and civil society organisations, including interregional organisations and networks.

It is a very significant day to talk about equality between men and women, because we celebrate Women's Day, remembering those who fought for labor and economic rights and for women's suffrage 100 years ago.
We have made great progress in these 100 years, but there is still much to be done, and true equality is still a dream, while discrimination against women is a reality.

I believe that each of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve true women's emancipation. Because there are many women in the world whose right to live is threatened, their dignity violated, and their freedom denied.
Allow me, on this Women's Day, to show my support and hope to all the women in the North African revolution who are fighting for their democratic rights.
Because a woman is not worth half a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere in the world.
Therefore, we are worth the same and deserve the same.
And I will continue to fight to achieve it. And as long as that equality does not exist, Women's Day will continue to exist.
Although many people do not want to see it, it is a reality that women earn half of what men do, and that domestic violence primarily affects women and children.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce all these facts in this Parliament, and of course I promise that I will continue to work.
Thank you, Mr President. I want to express my agreement with the opinion of the Members who have spoken here this morning and who insist on respect for Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest vote in favor will depend on the European Council's willingness to admit the role of the aforementioned institutions.
because the new mechanism we are talking about must be an important component of economic governance led by a European Union
capable of ensuring coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

In other words, we must avoid at all costs that this effort in which we are embarked ends up in the intergovernmental route, which is a dead end or the route of the predominance of a few States, because all of this would thwart the reform.
Dear colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this is one of the stones that reinforce and balance this delicate edifice.
There are essential points that need to be improved, so we must send the report back to committee.
It is not I who ends the parliamentary iteration of this report.
The initial proposal was bad.
This is what consumer associations were telling us at both national and European level.
and I especially appreciate the work of the Consumers' Union of Asturias and its president, the indefatigable Dacia Alonso.
we have managed to have the general principle of maximum harmonisation of the old Article 4 rejected.

It must be said very loudly that maximum harmonization, by establishing the same protection in all Member States, would mean a reduction in the protection of many consumers, since there is a greater tradition of protecting consumer rights in various countries.

I would like to emphasize that it is essential to ensure that the list of unfair contract terms is not exhaustive, allowing each Member State to increase the number of terms it considers unacceptable and invalid in consumer contracts.

reverse the burden of proof for individual clauses. So it is the merchants who have to demonstrate that the clauses that deviate from what is generally established have been negotiated individually. That the contractual clauses must be expressed in a clear and understandable form.
We continue to oppose the establishment of maximum harmonisation in relation to unfair terms.
The Eurobarometer tells us that 79% of traders believe that full harmonisation in this field will have little or no effect on their activities abroad.
Thank you, Mr President. Commissioner, allow me to begin by congratulating the rapporteur, Mr Swab and Mrs Gerhard on the excellent work they have done.
and a general reflection.
It's not that protectionism is increasing, but rather that the issue is not to cut back on rights that already exist in some of the member states.
Because if we want and pursue establishing a genuine internal market for relations between businesses and consumers, we must establish
establish a balance between the high level of protection of consumer rights and the defense of business competitiveness.
This balance involves agreeing on a minimum harmonization and allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations that improve consumer protection.
We cannot allow the adoption of a community standard to result in the lack of protection for many consumers and users.
I am pleased that negotiations in the European Parliament have improved, but I would like to emphasize that the rights that have been established so far should not be curtailed.

Mr. President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis may be an energy crisis, and that either we are not doing the necessary homework to avoid it or we are not doing it at the necessary speed to avoid it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum for Nature is calling on everyone to make a small gesture towards sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off their lights for an hour and many public administrations will follow their lead.
But it is not enough.
Europe cannot continue to depend on energies that are not its own, that are far away, or on insecure energies.
We need to help states build a new energy model in which renewable energies are at the heart of the new system.
And we must also support the awareness of new consumption patterns, because, without a doubt, renewables and efficiencies are the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I want to appeal to all the countries of the Union to join that call, to that will of five of them, including Spain, to increase CO2 emission reductions to 30%, because in this way we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being at the forefront of freedom and rights, is also at the forefront of its commitment to the sustainability of the planet.
Thank you very much. Most of the times I have spoken in this Parliament, I have done so to denounce violence against women and I am here again to fight against it.

I must say that not only do I not tire of it, but I consider it essential to continue speaking publicly about this violation of human rights, since there is no cause that can be defended without a sounding board, and this Parliament is the most suitable one.

I am a spokesperson available to defend all those women who suffer abuse daily and who need us, legislators, to pressure states to punish aggressors according to the severity of the crime and also to help the victims.

When it is estimated that a quarter of European women have suffered gender-based violence at least once in their lives and that children have also suffered in equal measure, I believe it is impossible not to call for greater commitment, such as that recognized by the Commission in its action plan.

I believe it is necessary to keep insisting again and again, to protect the victims as we already did in the European Protection Order for Victims, for which I was the rapporteur, and I hope that it will become a reality as soon as possible.
This report has enjoyed broad consensus and support from the outset, demonstrating that when it comes to addressing domestic violence that affects all members of the community,
family, children, elderly people, women and men, should not be a reason for political opportunism, because we are all honored to make progress in solving this social scourge.

The first thing is not to remain silent and the second thing is to get to work, because although we have been talking about gender violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

We must be doing something wrong, and therefore it is time to forget about demagogy and move from words to actions, providing more real help and the necessary attention so that women can live with dignity and security.
security. Let all the victims know that I will always be here to continue lending them my voice until we all manage to defeat this
a terrible enemy that sadly ends the lives of so many innocents. I say enough, enough already, and I ask all of you to say it with me.
Thank you very much, Mr President. Thank you very much, Commissioner. I agree with you that we need to listen to the citizens and regain confidence in the European project.
That is why today can be a great day for Europe and the construction of European society.

because with the approval of these reports we are not only moving towards the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we are also responding to the demands of citizens who are calling for more Europe and the strengthening of social rights.
Europe must respond to new global challenges and ensure that the European economy becomes a highly competitive social market economy that generates sustainable growth with more and better jobs.

But this objective must be based on the inclusion of a social clause in all legislation related to the internal market, which puts citizens at the center of our attention and priority and strengthens their social rights.
Finally, I would like to ask the Commission to present these proposals as soon as possible.
Mr. President, blue tongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, with it, to our public health as well.

A disease that we fought against through the use of live vaccines, which involves the creation of restricted zones for animal movement, because the use of these vaccines can lead to unwanted circulation of the virus in non-infected animals.

For these reasons, the use of the vaccine was limited to areas where infected animals had previously been found, creating a double disadvantage for cattle farmers: the disease on one hand, and the restrictions on the other.

But all these problems seem to be avoidable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to preventing the disturbances that can occur in the domestic cattle market, allows for the development of new and broader strategies, which is the truly important aspect of prevention in the fight against this disease.
For all these reasons, it is of vital importance for this sector that we amend the directive to allow its use and, moreover, that we do so as soon as possible.

Ladies and gentlemen, compliance with what our treaties dictate, especially regarding the correlation tables, cannot serve as an excuse for this regulation not to come into effect before summer, because with our delay, with their delay, we would only be harming the farmers.

First of all, I would like to thank the Committee on Petitions for the work it has carried out following the complaint filed by FEPEX, which is the Spanish Organization of Producers and Exporters of Fruits and Vegetables, based on the report published in 2007 by OLAF, the European Union's Anti-Fraud Agency.

I believe that the conclusions of that report are crystal clear and more than justify the fact that the European Commission had already set to work a long time ago to clarify the functioning of the entry price system, at least as far as the tomato sector is concerned.

However, not only has the Commission not intervened to address the potential pitfalls that may arise from the entry into force of the price regulation, but it has also negotiated a new agricultural agreement with Morocco without first resolving the shortcomings of the existing import regime.

Ladies and gentlemen, it is high time for the European Commission to take its responsibilities seriously and start investigating where the fraud is occurring, and eventually request the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I think that in no way should a new agreement with Morocco be ratified without the details we have outlined being resolved.

Our goal is not to prevent the signing of international agreements, but to ensure that these agreements do not seriously harm the interests of European productions and that the rules signed in these agreements are respected.

As far as the new agreement with Morocco is concerned, the European fruit and vegetable sector only asks for guarantees that the effective implementation of the agreed measures will be carried out. And this is only possible through the reform of the current entry price system.
We cannot have a new agreement with Morocco until we have a new entry price system.
We will not be able to ratify that agreement that the commission has already closed.

Moreover, if it is the responsibility of the Member States to carry out these checks, a significant financial effort should be required of them. However, it is also true that we have been calling for a long time for a European customs border system, similar to the one the United States has, to ensure effective control.

Thank you, Mr President. Commissioner, dealing with this report in Parliament has been complex, mainly because it involves these measures that require the approval of the World Trade Organization, and the preliminary proposal that the Commission sent to Parliament is different from the one sent to Geneva.
We believe that it is necessary to help Pakistan. We understand that exceptional trade preferences can be granted, provided that they take into account the sensitivities of the
European industry, and very especially the textile sector, which in communities such as the Valencian Community in Spain are severely suffering the consequences of the crisis.

But this report has allowed us to verify that the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade probably cannot be addressed with the urgency that these acts require, so we must learn for the future.

Will it help Pakistan? Yes, but not with the Commission's original proposals, as they do not take into account the effects of the European industry in terms of the implementation deadlines for sensitive and immunosuppressive products.
it would even delay the implementation of these measures because they do not coincide with the pending text scheduled to be approved by the WTO. We would be behind schedule.
Therefore, we consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal and we think we will have to vote against it.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to begin my speech by congratulating all those who have made it possible to reach an agreement.
It is an agreement that we should all be pleased about because it affects the daily lives of all citizens. But in the constructive spirit that characterizes me, I would like to make a few points.
First of all, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing accurate, relevant, but above all, comprehensible and uniform information.
for consumers about the components of textile products. Comprehensive information is useless if citizens are unable to decipher it.
We have achieved a positive step, necessary but not sufficient. We should go further and protect citizens who could become more vulnerable.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to establish a European sizing system based on body measurements, because the first thing we encounter when we go to buy a garment is the size.
That is why we should be much more ambitious and aim for size harmonization.
Mr. President, three notes on the situation created around the cucumbers.
I am of German descent and have great affection for that country, but it is evident that the German authorities have acted in this case with haste and imprudence.

On the other hand, if we analyze the European response, we notice that the one developed by the Food Safety Authority and the Commission has been weak, very subdued and imprecise. It has not been able to coordinate or direct.
Third, those affected are entitled to financial compensation quickly.
But for now, I propose to this Parliament that we organize a major European gastronomy exhibition in Brussels or here in Strasbourg, based precisely on cucumbers.
We must reclaim the lost honor, a phrase dear to the German writer Heinrich Bell. We must reclaim the lost honor of cucumber producers.
Europe is the appropriate setting for this.
First and foremost, we must express our sincere condolences for the 23 victims who have already lost their lives, 22 in Germany and one in Sweden.
And it must be said that this crisis is the most compelling proof that the European Union must improve its food alert system and its internal coordination, and improve them significantly.
The Member States involved have demonstrated slowness, inefficiency, and ineffectiveness, and to this day, after 23 deaths, we still do not know where the problem originates.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems caused by its irresponsible actions or inaction during times of crisis like the current one, resulting in cases of economic ruin and the destruction of jobs that were once essential.

of unemployment, powerlessness and, of course, a health crisis with extremely high health risks for the population. Because while you, from the commission, were echoing irresponsible statements from regional authorities,

German companies were very uninformed and quite irresponsible, with names and surnames of Spanish farms. Meanwhile, the population continued to be unknowingly exposed to the bacteria. Believing they were avoiding it, citizens were more exposed than ever to eating something that could harm them.

The European Commission is expected to propose to ministers at the Agriculture Council meeting in Luxembourg at 2 p.m. today that part of the 2.5 billion euros in unused remnants from the common agricultural policy be used.
those 2.5 billion euros to repair as much of the damage as possible.
To do this, it is necessary to seek a legal loophole that allows it. A legal loophole that has already been found on other occasions, such as mad cow disease or dioxins, and that should be found now.
Therefore, Commissioners, Ministers, today in Luxembourg you must live up to your responsibility.

The German authorities, moreover, given the irresponsible accusations made, should support this economic solution without a doubt and from the outset. And they should also fund, with their own resources, communication campaigns to restore the lost consumer confidence in fruit and vegetable production. Thank you.

Mr President, Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring back the dead, and I hope that what is being done will prevent more deaths and stop the chain of sick people who are suffering without having done anything to deserve it.

We don't know the causes, probably, but we do know some things that we must name. There has been negligence in political actions and there has been negligence in the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a city-state on another continent.

The arrogance that Mrs. Merkel and her Health Minister have in addressing other states with unusual frequency, if they had translated it into diligence and efficiency in coordinating, some of the things that have happened would not have occurred.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences on a state that has been the Spanish state and on the most important sector of agriculture. And it has led to family ruin for thousands of people and small business owners and has discredited the economy for a long time.
I ask you to go to the Council and demand full compensation for those affected, since we cannot ask for life for the dead.
and that the control systems are reviewed.
and that Mrs. Merkel be held accountable
And that he be asked for less arrogance and more diligence.
and that he is held responsible for some damage he has caused.
You can't ignore that Hamburg is in its prime.
he cannot ignore his responsibilities.
You can't hide behind a decentralized and federal state to cause the damage you've caused.

a little more humility, a little more good management and a little less conservatism would have been very useful so that this crisis would not have gotten out of hand and so that Spain and other farmers in the south would not have had to suffer its painful consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems and demand accountability because in Spain we are demanding it, Commissioner, from you, from the Council and from the German State.
President, we are facing a public health problem, an epidemic, as the Commissioner has said, and in response to this, we have been looking for a culprit, if not the cause.

The system has not worked. We have 22 dead, 1,600 affected, and we do not know the cause three weeks later. And, appealing to a precautionary principle without scientific basis, I repeat, without scientific basis, Spain is being blamed.
Ladies and gentlemen, Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
They were not contaminated. I repeat this because I have heard some contrary versions around here.
But to give you an idea of the importance of what these words have sparked, 300,000 jobs could be affected, a loss of confidence.
An epidemic knows no borders.

I agree with you, Commissioner. It knows no borders. We are calling for accountability for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately. Because Germany has a risk problem at the moment. It has a higher number of affected people, but Spain is not to blame.
We demand compensation.
And what unites us here today are the victims, because no one should feel as unprotected as we European consumers feel today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and accountability.

And it is my responsibility to denounce the German authorities who unjustly and hastily accused Spanish cucumbers and specifically the cooperatives of Málaga and Almería, which were model farms and will not recover from these accusations.
Thousands of jobless families are wondering why. Why do they need an answer and above all what will their future be like. Not just in Andalusia, but throughout agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that experts will quickly find a solution, I demand that the Commission, when it speaks with the Council today, asks for immediate economic and moral measures for all the producers who, from Andalusia and from all over Europe, look at us with indignation but with hope.
Instead of prioritizing European research and collaboration, German authorities have slandered and harmed cucumber producers and others.
and he has still not dismissed anyone in Germany or offered reparations commensurate with the damage caused,
It is Germany that has a serious credibility problem.
Mrs. Merkel's treatment of the southern countries in terms of agriculture and finance is intolerable.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Adenauer and Kohl.
None of that. A credit line. Morality.
Mr. President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, and some other countries share our reluctance to readily accept Brovilleta's call.

The coincidence, the criticism, is due to our status as peripheral countries, which in the end will be the ones to pay this singular tax that will be collected by the states of the European Union that have geographical centrality.
The ratio that inspires the Eurovignette is fraught with major contradictions, and the supporting discourse is becoming increasingly fragile.

Although the rationality of internalizing external costs is accepted as a starting point, in the end, the idea of penalizing only heavy-duty vehicles to alleviate congestion while leaving passenger cars out is not sustainable, as the old adage of "the polluter pays" is applied with evident discrimination.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the Eurovignette, which was conceived as a source of funding for infrastructure, will ultimately only allocate 15% to the funding of trans-European networks, and not in a mandatory manner.

but as a simple recommendation. So that the Minister of Finance of the time will allocate the funds raised to the purpose that he deems most appropriate to the interests of his country within the broad chapter of infrastructure.
The end result will be nothing other than another blow to road freight transport, which is currently the only mode that is enabling the internal market.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is much more harsh in a situation of economic crisis.

In this sense, the competitiveness of European products in global markets cannot afford experiments that could contribute to further deteriorating the precarious situation of the European economy by imposing new added costs.

The food crisis that has recklessly fallen upon Spanish products has resulted in unfair penalties and enormous losses to those who are penalized by the Eurovignette: freight transporters and farmers of high-quality crops.
These are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen, why the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party will vote against this draft directive.
You will all understand, dear colleagues, that in taking the chair, I express my sorrow and consternation at the passing of Jorge Semprún, which occurred a few hours ago at the age of 87.

In Jorge Semprún, we celebrate the former prisoner of the Buchenwald concentration and extermination camp, the fighter against the Nazi forces in France and against the Franco dictatorship in my country, Spain.
We also celebrate the most notable committed writer, a collaborator in particular of our program The European Book of the Year, and we also celebrate the convinced Europeanist politician.

I mourn his death, as do his fellow comrades and friends, and I will ask President Budgec to convey a message of heartfelt condolences and solidarity to his family and the Government of Spain, which I am sure we all share.
creation of an economic governance space governed by the principles of federalism adapted to European construction.
We can no longer close our eyes.
It is incoherent to have a single currency and at the same time lack the fiscal and financial instruments that this currency requires.
In concrete terms, therefore, we need the issuance of European debt, a clear rejection of competition between the debt issuance of the States, the creation of a genuine European public treasury, the
harmonization of tax policies that ensure equality among citizens, combat tax fraud, and help define a progressive European social policy based on effective public services.
These ideas are, I will be told, elementary.
But you have to repeat and repeat them, because no one listens.
And precisely because we do not listen, those dark times of which the poet Bertolt Brecht spoke are upon us.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. The current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing highlights the need for regional policy as the best instrument for reducing development disparities between regions and states.
At the same time, we can recover the positive image of Europe that citizens have recently associated only with tough austerity plans and social cuts.

The future cohesion policy, a pillar of solidarity in the European project and social justice, must take into account the following priorities: first, to strengthen social cohesion and integrate the challenges posed by the 2020 Strategy; second, to take into account the needs and characteristics that have been presented in the project.

geographical regions, especially the most disadvantaged ones. Third, maintain the principle of gradualism in the allocation of funds, so that regions do not abandon the objective of convergence, avoiding abrupt changes in the allocation of aid. And fourth, promote an efficient system.
equitable.
Finally, ladies and gentlemen, the authorities are implementing tough budget adjustment policies.
That is why the Union's support is necessary.
I hope the Council takes good note.

In defense of fundamental rights, I call on the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastián as European Capital of Culture, because I believe it has been chosen based on political criteria, which constitutes discrimination against the other cities that aspired to the title.

The president of the court said that it was chosen to support the peace process. And as far as I know, in Spain there is a terrorist organization called ETA that to this day has not abandoned its weapons and that two months ago managed to have its political arm, Bildu, govern among other municipalities, that of San Sebastián.
I don't think that from Europe we should give such a powerful voice to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and will make propaganda to distribute blame between victims and murderers.
Murderers? Where is the right to freedom and dignity?
certainly not in San Sebastián, where our colleagues like Mayor Oreja and Turgay, Salva or myself have to be escorted.
I believe in the culture of life, not in the culture of the shot. The Lord
can there be true culture without freedom
No and a thousand times no.
And when San Sebastián becomes a city free for all, let it present its candidacy again. And in the meantime, let them learn the culture of respect for those who think differently.
because tomorrow they may deserve it, but today, with Batasuna and its heirs in the institutions, they do not deserve it.
Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their fruitful collaboration in drafting it.
And I say the same thing about the other fellow deputies on the Committee of this Parliament.
The European Coal and Steel Community was created 60 years ago. There is no better way to commemorate this event than to debate energy infrastructure in Europe now.

Today, the European Union has clearly defined the objectives of its policy: a common European internal market, promotion of renewable energies as a means or instrument for combating climate change, security of supply, and diversification of its sources.

The Treaty of Lisbon has dedicated a title to energy, Article 21, where these commitments that I have just mentioned are formulated, as well as the promotion of the interconnection of energy networks.
Well, the objective of the report we have prepared is aimed at correcting energy infrastructures that, in the opinion of the European Commission, are outdated and poorly interconnected.
Thus, for example, we are seeing a spectacular increase in electricity generation from wind in the North Sea and the Baltic, with the immense potential for renewable energy in the south.
Europe and North Africa, with the problems arising from large-scale electricity storage, the needs for recharging electric vehicles, among many other urgent issues.
All of this is impossible to address today if we do not devise new networks and new connections both within the European Union and with third countries.

The task, therefore, in these coming years is to make progress in determining the necessary infrastructure. A. By establishing the criteria that will allow projects of European interest to be selected.

b. Suppressing energy islands.  
c. Ensuring the execution of these projects within reasonable timeframes and mediating formulas to resolve the contentious issue of the projects.
authorisation and licensing procedures in the Member States. D. Ensuring financing that attracts and boosts private investment without prejudice to the public support that is necessary.
Energy efficiency and savings, as well as smart grids, are central ingredients in the new design incorporated into the report because we have managed to make the report a great benefit for health.
It has been believed that by reducing energy demand, dependence on imports can be decreased, with a consequent effect on infrastructure needs.
A fundamental concern of this report from the outset has been the processing of licenses and authorizations intended to allow the execution of the necessary works.
are currently eternalized.
and are made permanent due to the opposition of the populations to seeing towers or other types of facilities grow in their vicinity.

To resolve this conflict, consideration has been given to early information for citizens and establishing a warning system in the event that the authorities of a state do not respond to a request within a reasonable time frame.
We are facing ambitious goals that require the cooperation of everyone.
In this sense, companies in the sector are essential, as they rightly call for a stable regulatory framework, which is the best way to ensure the financing of their efforts.
So far, the European Union's energy policy, both outside its borders and within its territory, has lacked a decidedly European impetus.
Europe needs to speak with a single voice, a voice that is well audible and resonates fully in the vault of the European edifice, because it is from our energy fragility that we have disappeared.
summoning the strength to build an energetically solid and vigorous Europe, a worthy successor in this anniversary year of that great invention that was the ECSC, our cradle precisely.
Mr President, every time there is a commitment that allows us to move forward, we should be pleased, but I also don't think that the commitment we have reached is something to die of happiness over.
We must be prudent in the moments of happiness we experience.

Account audits are currently hampered by the concentration and lack of independence of auditors and do not contribute to generating that much-desired trust that would revitalize our economy.
it would not be out of the question to consider eliminating the legal requirement for financial audits.
Why not?
If we want to regain the confidence of the markets and in the markets, we must carry out a thorough reform of the audits so that they represent a genuine added value and not just a legal burden.
The big accounting firms use audit services as a calling card for their future clients.
Once they are familiar with the company, they offer more expensive complementary services to often compensate for the low prices of the strict audit.
We have a problem of price distortion in the sector.

These complementary services already account for almost 50% of the billing, so the big auditors don't want to lose the audit services, but not because of the audit itself, rather to maintain and increase the complementary services.
The second major obstacle to free competition in the sector is the oligopoly of the four major players who dominate the European markets by more than 90%.
As such, oligopolies control prices and establish barriers to entry for new competitors, leveraging intangibles such as Marx's international image.

It is true that this brand image may be based on certain advantages, but it does not always imply greater efficiency, given the legislative diversity in the accounting states that are susceptible to particular treatment in each member state.
I share the objectives of the Green Paper, independence and concentration of the sector, and the means to be used, rotation, joint audits,
solicitation, reinforcement of professional skepticism, prevalence of substance over form, separation of audit services from non-audit services.
I have tried to incorporate them into my report to the extent that the parliamentary majorities and the modest scope of the report have allowed.
Ladies and gentlemen, this is only a small step towards achieving new legislation that will address the issues in the field of audits that have led us to this terrible economic crisis.

The directive on the rights of victims of crime, including terrorism, and as a Spaniard who has directly suffered the cruelty of the terrorist organization ETA, I want to thank President Busek for his support for my country and its victims.

We must strive to further integrate the sector into the value chain, ensure that there is no quota distribution, especially in certain areas, and promote quality policies.

But without any doubt, with our positive vote and with all that remains to be done, today many cattle farmers will be able to see this Parliament that has defended their labor rights, the most basic of all, which is the right to be able to live with dignity from the income of their work.
B has well pointed out the disastrous consequences that the approval of this agreement would entail.
Because this agreement that extends quotas for certain fruit and vegetable products, when the figures in the current agreement are not respected, is absolutely meaningless.

It is worth noting that the Spanish Federation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters reported to the Committee on Petitions of this Parliament the massive entry of tomatoes through Perpignan at a price lower than that set in the agreement.
Illegal situations such as the one described place the European farmer at a competitive disadvantage.
It should also be added that our farmers must adhere to strict environmental and social quality standards that our Moroccan partners do not always respect.
To conclude, I will point out the issue of the Sahara.
According to the United Nations Charter, the Sahara is an autonomous territory and the exploitation of its resources must benefit precisely the local population.
Moreover, it constitutes a zone over which the UN does not recognize the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Morocco.
The European Union must ensure compliance with international law.

I am in favor of an agreement with Morocco, in favor of an agreement that establishes rigorous control mechanisms from the European Union in relation to quotas and prices. An agreement that fights against dumping, that does not exploit Moroccan farmers and, above all, that dignifies our European farmers.
it is certainly not this agreement.

In the fourth year, the Committee on Petitions of the European Parliament requested the European Commission to modify the entry price system for fruits and vegetables in the Union, a system that is facilitating the fraudulent entry of products from third countries, as stated by the Union's own Anti-Fraud Agency, OLAF.
They are mainly Moroccan tomatoes.
The same request was included in a declaration signed last year by the governments of Spain, France, and Italy.

This fraud is resolved by amending the implementing regulation of the Common Market Organisation for Agricultural Products, because the alignment of the Customs Code does not resolve the problem, Commissioner.

For several years, I have been advocating within the Popular Party for the need to halt new concessions to Morocco until the European Union equips itself with the necessary instruments to ensure compliance with the current agreement.
The European Commission argues that it is the Member States that must ensure control of imports.

However, what the Commission does not say is that the entry price system is in effect, and this system prevents national customs authorities from properly tracing the prices declared by importers to verify that there are no irregularities.

Modify the implementing regulation of the CMO for agricultural products and we will have solved part of the problem. Because if not, the legal loophole in European regulations prevents national authorities from doing their job properly.

are ceasing to be credible because they are not contributing to solving the crisis.
Summits where the same agreements are reiterated time and time again.
