Thank you, Madam President. From the European Parliament, I would like to pay tribute today to all women, because despite the significant progress we have made since that March of 1911, when women took to the streets to demand the right to vote and better working conditions, I believe that true gender equality is still far from being achieved.
Today women can work without having to ask anyone's permission, but in many cases they still earn less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
We must also remember the women in the rural world, whose work is ignored.
I believe that another uncomfortable reality, but one that must continue to be denounced, is violence against women.

This year alone, there has already been an excessive number of women murdered, not to mention the serious threats made by those who believe they have the right to exercise physical or psychological violence against them.
It is time to say enough and to say it loud and clear.
From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Protection Order for Victims and to the Victims Directive presented by the Commission, which will be voted on, God willing, next June.
We also have to say, and I would like to remind, that motherhood continues to be an obstacle to women's progression and I believe it is a trend that should be changed.
I want to send a message of hope and with many women, with the help of more and more men, we have to move forward on the path of equality, of opportunities, rights and also of duties.
We have come a long way, but there is still much to be done.
I have to admit that I don't believe deeply and absolutely in quotas but I have to tell you that something has to be done and I agree with

I am grateful to many of my colleagues and, of course, to Mrs. Reding for opening this debate and for moving forward on this path so that women can regain the place they deserve, and she can count on my support.

Mr. President. In a time of economic crisis and budget cuts that is affecting public health and in which, as in the community where I live, research centers like the Príncipe Felipe, specialized in diabetes, are left without funding, this resolution is more appropriate than ever. It is absolutely fitting.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes and we need a Council recommendation that tells the states that they have to increase research, including with stem cells, that they have to coordinate their results to optimize them, that they have to establish programs for healthy eating and lifestyle habits.

In short, we must prioritize people's health above all else, and in this case, investigating, coordinating, and implementing national programs coordinated by the Commission, while demanding results on diabetes, is about ensuring the quality of life of Europeans and guaranteeing their very lives.

If we allocate more money to this, some will take a little longer to collect. But those who are currently having problems will certainly have a better quality of life, and we, as States, as Council, and as Commission, will be fulfilling one of our obligations, which is to ensure the health of our citizens.
Mr President, of the many issues that this debate raises, I would like to highlight that of the emissions trading market - a market that was born with defects, certainly.
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have led to a drastic reduction in the price of carbon. In other words, the price is so low that it is cheap to pollute.
It is therefore urgent to reform the design of a policy on that market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, the entire green policy of the European Union.
If emission rights are not valued, the increase in emissions is being encouraged. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques. And what's worse,
The funding of important projects, such as those related to energy efficiency or carbon storage plants, will be jeopardized.
This is the risk.
It is up to us, the Commission and Parliament, to conjure it up.
Mr. President, few asylum seekers are permanently resettled in Europe.
My country, Spain, has barely begun with the experience.
The cases are, however, of urgent necessity.
The deputies have verified this on the ground during a trip to the Iraqi camps of Palestinian origin in Syria. We also received news from Tunisia shortly afterwards.
Another more institutional aspect is the balance of power between Parliament and the Council.
Our opponent, the valiant Ruiz Tavares. There are many good parliamentarians, but few with as much tenacity as Ruiz Tavares.
She has fought for the European Parliament to retain the new powers gained after the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I cannot forget the ongoing work carried out by UNHCR, without which success would not have been possible either.
UNHCR has made us all aware of the urgency of the report so that the funds can be used as soon as possible, now that they are so needed.
And finally, many thanks, Commissioner, and I hope that we will also give you and your good heart the satisfaction of pushing through the asylum package next month.

The European social model that we are so proud of is not only based on our pension, education, and healthcare systems, but also on a way of understanding the balance between employers and employees within companies.

The labor reform that has been approved by the Spanish government, without dialogue and without consensus, breaks with that social model and distances us from the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, both in terms of job creation and in terms of job quality.
Labour reform alone does not create jobs; economic growth does.
What a labor law does define, however, are the conditions under which workers enter companies, the conditions under which they remain in them, and the conditions under which they leave them.
And with this reform, 80% of workers will be left unprotected because they will not be subject to collective agreements, and they can be fired due to a decrease in company revenue,
they can unilaterally modify their schedules. What is clear is that workers will enter with greater precariousness, remain in the labor market with more fear, and leave it with less compensation.

That is why this reform, which attacks the European social model and bets on the competitiveness of the Spanish economy only in relation to workers' conditions, deserves a general strike like the one that must be called tomorrow in Spain in defense of this social model.

Mr President, Mr Barroso, let me start by saying that the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party finds your approach correct and endorses the two packages you have presented today, both the employment package and the solidarity aid for Greece, which is closely related to the coherence of your proposal.
It is undeniable, ladies and gentlemen, that we are living through difficult times and events every day remind us that the crisis is still far from being resolved.
it has inevitably returned the spotlight to Spain.
The alarms in the markets have been triggered without justification, fueled in part by statements that I believe, Mr. President, are inopportune.
In the context of an important election in which both contenders cite my country as a dialectical element of confrontation.
Of course we do not appreciate any of the references.
On the other hand, some people, in order to divert attention from their own problems, also deal with us with little political tact.
Today here too, some have been lacking in finesse, as the Italians would say, and there has been a certain lack of political delicacy.
Ladies and gentlemen, the situation in the markets does not reflect Spain's strength.
We are a solvent country with the full capacity to meet our debts.
Spanish debt remains below the European Union average and the Spanish Government is fully committed to meeting the deficit targets agreed with the European Union.
Mr Rajoy has never said, Mr Esbóvaga, that he cannot meet the objectives set by the European Union.
He said the opposite, that he is willing to fulfill each and every one of his goals and reiterates it every day.

In the few months since it took office, the Spanish Government has adopted and will continue to adopt very ambitious measures to ensure fiscal consolidation and lay the foundations for improved competitiveness, job creation, and growth.
The IMF's forecasts, by the way, from yesterday, the IMF itself admits, predate the analysis of the decisions and measures taken by the Spanish government at present.
Other measures we have adopted: the general state budget for 2012, which in our opinion will ensure that the deficit target is met this year. The Organic Law on Budgetary Stability.

will present a reform of education and healthcare that will involve a 10 billion euro adjustment. The reform of the financial sector will also undoubtedly contribute to financial institutions having to allocate more than 50 billion.
In summary, Spain is meeting the objectives set by the Commission, and what we are asking for is responsibility from everyone.

We need to save ourselves together, and Spain with everyone, without any doubt, and there is no contribution to criticism from one side or the other. Either all countries are capable of standing together and contributing to growth and a new path, or, if not, it will naturally be difficult for us to move forward on the terms proposed by the Commission.
Do you want to make Mr. Rajoy, the President of the Government, the main character?
I think that's fine, I wouldn't have any problem.
But Mr. Rajoy is not the protagonist of the crisis.

The protagonist of the crisis is the legacy received by the Spanish socialist, communist, and green left, which has left the worst legacy ever left by any government, when they received the best legacy ever had by any government.
Mr President, this morning I read in a major German newspaper that Spain and Argentina are in dispute over an oil company.
This is simply the wrong way to approach the matter.
The conflict is between Europe and Argentina and beyond, with that great European value of legal certainty and its respect in international commercial relations.
European institutions have excellent legal experts who can find the appropriate instruments in the original or derived Community law to neutralize the arbitrariness of the Argentine authorities.
I am a modest professor of Public Law and I offer to collaborate with them.
The credibility of the European Union before its citizens is currently at stake.

Thank you, Mr. President. In the Committee on Agriculture, we share the ultimate goal of this directive, which is to try to guide the composition of our energy mixes through taxation. However, we are facing a very complex debate.

fraught with challenges in economic, social, and environmental terms. What is important is to maintain those balances that help us make more progress in the environmental sphere, yes, but that also do not harm us economically and do not create greater social crises than the ones we are already experiencing.
This is the case with agriculture.

As everyone knows, energy costs increasingly represent a very important part of the fixed costs of our agricultural holdings. At a time when, moreover, we are engaged in a debate that combines the crises in the raw materials markets with a prospect of loss of aid and one of the health and environmental essentials that make up their profitability margins.
...that is why we have fundamentally asked for two things...

The first, the maintenance of zero-rate deductions in the energy component, now linked to the drafting and implementation of energy efficiency and savings strategies in rural areas, and the incorporation of the
within sectors considered to be at risk of carbon leakage, in order to be able to access the deductions allowed in the CO2 emissions bracket.
In other words, a more environmentally demanding policy, but one that maintains the balances that make our rural areas viable at a time of change and uncertainty.
We are living through a major controversy that is fundamentally based on the concepts of austerity and growth.
If you listen to the noise that is being created, it would seem that the idea of growth is a bright invention of these days.
Nothing could be further from the truth.
In Europe, the pact that is precisely called the Stability and Growth Pact has been in effect since 1997.

That is why a large part of the policies carried out by European institutions, such as those on regional cohesion and research, are growth-oriented policies that aim to promote the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, and I am addressing the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have the most opportunities to make themselves heard, we should not feel any hesitation in engaging in that debate, which we can face with our heads held high.
This is my minority opinion among the non-enrolled.
Thank you very much, Madam President. Allow me, first of all, to thank all my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs, for their help with this report, which has made it much stronger.

We all know that the twentieth anniversary of the launch of the single market is being celebrated, which should be the driving force behind economic activity and growth in Europe, a key factor in overcoming the crisis and achieving the objectives of Europe 2020.

Over these 20 years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development, with a broad framework of consumer protection, growth, and rights that generate dynamism and security.
and trust. Transparency, a basic principle of democracy and good governance, to which Commissioner Bernier referred this afternoon, and cooperation between the Commission and Parliament.
It is now time to develop the regulatory framework concerning the protection and training of consumers, and particularly of vulnerable consumers.
We know that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, makes it difficult to adopt a comprehensive legislative instrument.
This obliges us to address the problem of vulnerability from a cross-cutting analysis, which takes into account the different needs, capacities, and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, being aware of the current shortcomings, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
While an ambitious proposal, it is not enough to protect vulnerable consumers because their vulnerability stems precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the
information they receive or of the options available or of their lack of knowledge of the existing complaint and compensation systems, especially in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

This is why, in order to address the shortcomings, that is, the problems, it is necessary to adopt a strategy to strengthen vulnerable consumers and for both the Commission and the Member States to introduce specific measures in their legislation to ensure adequate protection.

that goes beyond mere information, especially in those areas where the level has been shown to be higher and where the highest number of consumer complaints are recorded. The financial sector, whose complexity means that potentially any consumer can become vulnerable.

Therefore, the financial services industry is urged to redouble its efforts to provide comprehensible, truthful information, with clear explanations and direct language about the nature of the products and services it offers. The food sector, in relation to advertising

of foods high in fats, salt and sugar and to children and young people, who are most susceptible to advertising for these foods. The transport sector, which often still struggles when vulnerable people travel. The energy and telecommunications sector,

where the lack of transparency in some cases creates an added difficulty for consumers. For example, in the energy sector, when determining the tariff that best suits their needs. In access to justice, where consumers may find it difficult to access economic mechanisms.
existing.
That is why we are asking the Commission and the Member States, and allow me to sound a warning note to the Spanish Minister for Justice, Mr Gallardón, not to backtrack on rights.
And it goes against the trend of these difficult times. It involves using intelligence and good governance in favor of alternative dispute resolution in consumer matters.
Finally, it should be noted that any one of us can become a vulnerable consumer. Thank you very much and I would like to thank all the SADOS for their help in strengthening this report.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. The truth is that I have a sense of hopelessness, almost of frustration, that I must share with someone.
it's going to allow me to do it this afternoon with you.

This is the third or fourth debate we have had in this House recently on the situation of youth unemployment across Europe. And debate after debate, while youth unemployment rates are soaring in some Member States, we are already close to 50%.

50% of the labor force rate, while many of them are already running out of any type of social or unemployment coverage, while all of this is happening, while we are moving from a situation that evolves from being worrying to being

from the unsustainable to the dramatic. The Commission presents itself once again in this Parliament, in this Chamber, as if it were a political commentator, as if it were just another analyst and not the true Government of the Union, which is what it is and what we need.
Commissioner, governing means setting priorities, taking the lead, and doing so with the aim of achieving a goal or objective, and the commission is not doing that.

Governing is not about making a simple restructuring of funds, or even making and announcing it, in order to save face before public opinion, but about raising an ambitious, long-lasting and rapid strategy to end youth unemployment.

Governing is not about resigning in the face of a youth unemployment rate above 20% and being satisfied with a pilot project of four million euros, which is ridiculous given the situation, given the magnitude of the problem we are facing.

We must govern without succumbing to the pressures of the College of Commissioners or other member states of the Council, which are trying to convince us that the only way out of this financial crisis, this new wave of recession, is by giving up wages, labor rights, or compensation, and that our only future as a generation is one of precariousness.

Because if this were true, Commissioner, that we only gain competitiveness through precariousness and that we will only become more competitive by being more precarious, then Zimbabwe would be the most competitive country and it is not.
This is true of Sweden, Finland, and Denmark, which are precisely characterized by a model of exemplary relationships and also by a model of labor rights and guarantees.
Mr. President, employment is much more than a right of citizenship. It is an instrument of connection with the system, it is an instrument of social integration and

And therefore, the more unemployment, the greater the political disaffection. And that's why, Commissioner, I won't accept that you talk about issues of competence in order to do nothing about youth unemployment.

Because, moreover, Commissioner, when you have had to interpret the treaties in a lax manner to create, for example, the Financial Stability Fund, you have done so. And when the treaties have had to be reformed to comply with or satisfy the delusions of a Member State regarding austerity, we have also done so.
So, what is it that I want to tell you?
There's the youth employment guarantee, for example. It doesn't need to be explained to you.

Advocate for increased funding. Use, if necessary, the European Social Fund as an instrument. Design an application mechanism with funding and solidarity that helps the most those with the highest unemployment rates. Push to change this policy of social suffocation for countries that are doing the worst. And remember that behind every figure there is a person who is going through a tough time.
So, you will think, as I do, that the least important thing is who has the power, because for the citizens as a whole, especially...
Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, I would like to thank the Inter Commission for the work they have done, as well as the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs.

In general, we are dealing with a good regulation of the S.G. Plus that is necessary, particularly in some actions to control the rules of imports of textile products that could harm the production of the European Union.
But we are concerned about the exclusion, starting in 2014, of certain countries classified as upper-middle income from the GSP. Countries, for example, like Latin America.
Because what happens with these middle-income countries that have undiversified exports?
diversified? Why not introduce a criterion for export diversification?

Because two speeds could be produced in this scenario. Countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, and Ecuador would benefit from this, distinguishing themselves from potentially developed countries like China and Brazil.

Therefore, I believe that we must support a transition period and that amendments will be presented with this transition period to adapt to this situation for these countries and give them the opportunity to open negotiations and trade agreements with them so that they can benefit from it.

I already supported Mrs. Anadelcheva's report when I was able to accompany her on the mission to the Congo together with other parliamentarians. And indeed, I verified that I have seen few peoples with a greater manifest will to make democracy and participate in it.
But a people to believe in democracy needs to believe in its state and its government as well. And that won't be possible just with electoral support or with external support.
They also need there to be a demand to fight corruption and to break the indecent paradox of living in poverty in one of the countries richest in resources in the world.

And it must be said and denounced that part of the violence they experience is imported or at least encouraged by those unscrupulous multinationals that, from Europe or other continents or other states, are capable of participating in corruption without caring that they encourage struggles over those resources in order to gain the favor of those who govern certain territories.

That is why, Mr. Astro, although it is not strictly within your purview, I say that a greater demand for traceability and transparency from European multinationals and others from other continents that collaborate there would be as useful for the development of that people as the aid we can provide at the electoral level and at the technical level.
Mr. President, to the rapporteurs for the valuable work they have presented.
Colleagues, we are now debating package 2, after having approved package 6, after almost all the heads of state and government agreed on two international treaties outside the constitutional order.
After many other European regulations have created more Community authorities for banking supervision, stock market supervision, insurance supervision, and for economic system risks.
An array of texts and more texts of reports, proposals addressing new economic valuation criteria, new procedures, new protocols.
procedures, we must not stop and apply what we have already approved
In the face of the instability experienced by the European continent, what is needed is just the opposite: stability and legal security.
We do not need a mishmash of successive legal findings.
I don't know, dear colleagues, if I am dreaming.
The situation that the rescue entails is very worrying.
Spanish citizens are not being told the whole truth about the new debt, as the Spanish government and state are assuming private debt as public debt.
The Spanish government has requested aid that it previously said it did not want, and is presenting it ridiculously as a triumph, as some colleagues warned in this debate.
There is no triumph, only failure with Bankia and others.

I insist, there is no more correct policy for Europe than the one sponsored by the French government, behind which parliamentary ranks must close. We will not get out of debt without harmonious growth of all and of the whole.

Supervision as called for in the two reports, yes, all the supervision that is necessary, but simultaneous growth is essential, anti-speculative as well, as alluded to in some of the measures of both reports and other reports too.
Please, clarity and transparency too, balance, as my colleague Sánchez Presedo said before.
Madam President, since I entered this Parliament, I have continually denounced female genital mutilation.
That silent and accepted crime that millions of women and girls around the world suffer. 70 million, I repeat, 70 million.

...an unbearable figure......for those who take the time to study......the terrible consequences......of these practices......that hide under the guise......of psychological reasons......of health, religious......all of them false...

The truth is that female genital mutilation, preferably performed on girls as young as 14 or even one year old, can lead to death from hemorrhagic shock and, in the best-case scenario, cause severe psychological trauma.
From Europe, we must fight with all our strength to eradicate this violation of human rights that undermines the right to equal opportunities and endangers health.
Ladies and gentlemen, this is about abuse, cruelty, torture against girls. And this degrading treatment also exists in Europe.
To do this, we must activate all the prevention mechanisms available to our legal system, and I encourage our judges to take action to prevent genital mutilation.
of girls in Europe, punishing those who carry it out. May the law in Europe speak with a single voice when it comes to combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I call on civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still a long way to go, but many of us will not stop because we owe it to 70 million mutilated women.
Thank you, Mr President. Commissioner, I am fully aware that one of the reasons we approved the dairy package was to gradually adapt the sector to a market without milk quotas in 2015.

But it is also true that every time this liberalization date approaches, uncertainty in the sector increases due to the lack of a clear exit strategy. The reasons why the sector demands prudence and reflection from us regarding the decision we have to make also increase.

Reasons, for example, such as the belief in maintaining vineyard planting rights or maintaining sugar quotas, at least until 2020. Reasons such as the uncertainty that exists in the sector about the real effects of the dairy package and whether

...we will have had time to make a serious assessment of them......and also reasons such as uncertainty about where the common agricultural policy is heading......and especially its budget, that is, the part of the income......that does not come from the markets and that affects our producers...

So, what do we ask you, Commissioner? That you pass it on to Mr. Cholos. That we do not engage in a makeshift policy of dismantling our protection system without a serious and rigorous analysis, because the effects on our producers are irreversible.

postpone the end of the quota until 2015, until a date that provides security to the sector and opens up an open and transparent debate on the regulation mechanisms, because the markets are still more unfair and the producers are increasingly defenseless.
Thank you very much, Mr President. Many Members of this Parliament have listened to the voice of the citizens, the voice of the street.
Commissioner, you said this is a yes or no agreement.
we Members of this Parliament also have a responsibility for the 'yes' or the 'no'.

yes, it is an act solution

piracy and another new legislative framework for the digital environment, which we have requested repeatedly from the Socialist Group, we are asking for it again
It's your chance.
Do not turn your back on society because tomorrow it will shrink and you will have no way out.
for things to improve, it is sometimes necessary to accentuate the chaos.
The sense of powerlessness was so great that Europe had to react. And it has done so for the good of all. Because the big winner of this past summit has been the euro.
And with this victory, hope has returned that Europe will emerge from its paralysis by moving from reflection to action.
At this summit, ladies and gentlemen, it was as necessary to adopt short-term measures to ensure financial stability as it was to adopt long-term measures to address the shortcomings of the Union.
In this case, the immediate was essential in order to continue working towards what was important.
It is imperative to send a message that the euro is a common, irrevocable, and irreversible project.

We welcome, ladies and gentlemen, such important decisions as the one to empower the European Stability Mechanism to directly recapitalize banks, which will break the vicious circle between bank debt and sovereign debt, a thesis always defended, by the way, by the current Spanish government.
In addition, it will serve to intervene in the markets in support of the public debt of countries that meet their commitments regarding public deficit and reforms.
These were necessary decisions to ensure financial stability, which must be the European Union's top priority in the short term.
This is not the time, ladies and gentlemen, for certain countries to resort to nationalist maxims and put obstacles in the way.
I have already said it, it is time to bet on Europe.
Spain, ladies and gentlemen, is adopting and implementing in record time the most ambitious reformist agenda in Spanish democracy, which includes a profound labor reform.
In addition, a financial reform based on total transparency is being carried out, demonstrating its commitment to fiscal consolidation and the achievement of deficit targets.

We also welcome the decision to launch a process for greater economic integration through four blocks: a banking union, a fiscal union, a common economic policy framework, and strengthening democratic agility.
Mr President, the community first and then Europe has always been not only about overcoming crises, but also about emerging stronger from them.
I'm glad that once again we've managed to make it.
Dear colleagues, we have our full attention focused on the banks, which we repeatedly hear described as the lifeblood of the social body.
This image is probably accurate, but let's keep in mind that every body is supported by a spine and joints.
Well, the backbone and the joints of that social body we call Europe are precisely its transport networks and its energy infrastructures.
It is essential, as is being said this afternoon here in the chamber, to mobilize private funding and, where appropriate, public funding.
And it is also an opportunity to promote the issuance of private debt guaranteed by European institutions specifically intended for these purposes and open to any investor.
Congratulations to the speakers for their work and also to the Commission for its clear support for these projects.

Mr President, dear Commissioner, Minister, as I welcome the new presidency, I am a veteran member of the now-defunct Non-Aligned Movement that your country led, and I fervently wish for the territorial integrity of Cyprus in the face of military occupations.

defend the rights of Spanish consumers and act against the reduction of rights and the functions of consumer associations that the current Spanish government intends to impose.

first reading agreement, which was very important because it brought into force the regulation that we had approved in 2010 and needed to be revised.
not because it was bad legislation, the legislation was very good, but as has been said, recent events occurred that are well known and demonstrated that there was a certain
it was necessary to correct it so that it would not happen again and specific points of vigilance and security of the medicines once marketed had to be reinforced.

obligation to declare the real reasons and motives that have led to this withdrawal or suspension of a medicinal product's authorization.

The rapporteur's work, Mr President, is very good, but I want to take this opportunity to say here, in this context, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can see.
We forget what Pufendorf already taught us, that general laws should be few and their meaning must be understood correctly.
Therefore, those who promulgate it must employ all the clarity that is possible.
And Montesquieu always insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
In other words, we must avoid esoteric jargon, full of neologisms and unjustified linguistic borrowings, because it generates a malicious network where traps lurk and arbitrariness takes hold.
We deal with very complex issues in this Parliament, but it is our obligation to convey them to the public in a comprehensible and accessible way.
It is common for even legal professionals themselves, judges, and lawyers, to become frustrated with our texts.
Good prose, dear colleagues, is the legislator's courtesy and a way of demonstrating their respect for the citizen.

Thank you, Mr. President. There is, ladies and gentlemen, an old principle that has passed from the legal sphere to the political one, and that is pacta sunt servanda. In other words, agreements are meant to be kept.
By this I mean the important measures adopted by the European Council in June to resolve the crisis affecting us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, market pressure has eased and they have welcomed decisions that can break the vicious circle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as plans to move towards a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro in an irreversible manner.
The European Council, observed last week, contains, ladies and gentlemen, undeniable positive aspects. The conclusions on progress towards the Banking Union are satisfactory.
The A27 agreement is also positive for the launch of the banking supervisor. Finally, it is appropriate that the launch be entrusted to the Eurozone's Ministers of Economy.
But it will allow you to make a critical judgment of the biased interpretations that have been made unilaterally of it.

It is not acceptable, ladies and gentlemen, to make private interpretations that may distort the mandate given to the Ministers of Economy, nor do we approve of presenting as agreements matters that were not even discussed.
It is urgent to move towards a single supervisory mechanism that must cover all financial entities.

among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect, or the concept of human security.

it is that of cybersecurity and cyber defence, reports that we also debated today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European cybersecurity strategy.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again the defence of the general interests upheld by the Commission and Parliament comes up against national egoisms entrenched in the Council.
Given the prior acceptance of the legitimacy of both positions, it is inexcusable not to reach a balance.
The relevance of the next financial framework is unquestionable.
The Spanish delegation of the EPP and I, on its behalf, reiterate that the Presidency's proposal is, in our opinion, unacceptable.
A cut of 75 billion euros on the already inevitably meager proposal of the European Commission is sterile and useless.
And that's not all. The new direct cut to agricultural and cohesion policies means crossing the red line that Spain indicated from the start of the negotiations.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is no longer time to argue about a supposed dichotomy between austerity and growth.
Some of us are making proven efforts and sacrifices for deficit correction.
But Spain, like so many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity, and create jobs.
And with this budget, you're not getting anywhere. On the contrary, the budget line is like a missile.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with much fewer resources, especially if what there is is distributed unfairly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that simply means the disappearance of growth opportunities and, above all, any vestige of solidarity. And this is precisely the direction the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path indicated by the Commission, who should be thanked for their efforts in pointing out a different route.

At this point, in the need for the Union, in the need for shared efforts, I want to thank Mr. Barroso for making a strong statement the other day in Cádiz interpreting the treaties for a supposed secessionist within the Union.

made it clear, unequivocally, as the guardian of the treaties, that if a part of a member state separates as an independent state, it becomes considered a third country and, therefore, the declarations and effects of the treaty itself will not affect it.

I hope, Mr. Vice President, in the absence of the President, that this can be taken into account and that this safe and consistent doctrine of the commission can continue to remain alive for the guarantee of all.
